loans.use: To purchase fishnets and pig food

loans.name: Celina João

texts.pt:
Celina João C. é natural da província Maputo, casada maritalmente e mãe de 2 filhos com idade entre o primeiro com 16 e o segundo com 13 anos respectivamente ambos ainda estudantes. Para alem dos filhos sustenta dois enteados que vive com eles.

Celina estudou até 7ªclasse e parou por falta de condições financeiras, ela nasceu a 30 km da cidade de Maputo e aos 7 anos mudou se com a família para cidade, aos 15 anos juntou se com o marido e ao mesmo tempo iniciou o negocio. O qual consiste na venda de produtos alimentares e de higiene. Onde tem um lucro mensal de 25000,00mt e consegue poupar algum no final de cada mês.

Para Celina este é o primeiro empréstimo na Hluvuku e no Kiva, também já solicitou noutras instituições nos valores seguintes ( 5000,00mt, 10000,00mt, 15000,0mt e 30000,00mt)  onde aplicou na compra de material de construção da sua casa e aumento do seu estoque/mercadoria.

Celina tem como sonhos ou planos futuros comprar uma viatura, mobilar a sua casa e dar melhores formações aos filhos.
texts.en:
Celina João C. was born in Maputo, Mozambique. She is married and the mother of two kids, ages 13 and 16, both enrolled in school. She also has two step-children. Celina's schooling was interrupted in 7th Grade, due to her family's financial constraints. She got married at age 15, and has been in the business of selling food and cleaning products ever since. With a monthly income of 25000,00 mt, Celina is able to to save some money each month. She has taken out and repaid other loans before (in the amounts of 5000,00, 10000,00 and 15000,00), but this is her first loan with Hluvuku and Kiva--which she used to purchase more products to sell and construction materials to finish building her house. Celina's hopes for the future include being able to buy a car, to furnish her house and to give her children a better education.

Translated from Portuguese by Aline Pereira, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying and selling general products

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Savoeun

texts.en:
Savoeun N., 43, and her husband, Vong N., 33, were married in 1998 and have three children; two sons and one daughter. Two of their children attend school and the other one is too young to attend school. The family lives in a small village about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Savoeun has been selling grocery for seven years. Vong assists his wife in grocery selling. They buy them from Prek Phnao market for resale. They hope their business will be able to support their children to study at the highest level in school as possible.

Savorun is requesting a loan of $700 to purchase additional grocery items for resale

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for resale.

loans.name: Soy

texts.en:
Soy L., 36, and her husband, Ponlork Phom, 49, live in a small village about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh. They have five children; three sons and two daughters. Two children are garment factory workers and the other three children attend school. Soy L.'s mother also lives with her.

Soy has been a garment factory worker for eight years. Her husband has been in the army for twenty years. He travels to work by motor taxi and the costs are high. Soy is requesting a loan of US$1000 to purchase one motorbike for her husband to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase one motorbike for driving to work.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase pigs and pig food to start a pig-breeding business

loans.name: Sam-At

texts.en:
Sam-at Y., 32, and her husband, Hout Thol, 29, live in a small village about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh. They have been married for eight years and have four children; one son and three daughters. Three children attend school and the other one is still young and stays at home.

Sam-at has been a garment factory worker in Phnom Penh for ten years. Her husband has been a full time employee in an electrical shop in Phnom Penh for seven years. Sam-at is requesting a loan of US$900 to build a restroom for the family house.

loans.use: To build one restroom to use in the family house

loans.name: Saroeun

texts.en:
Saroeun E., 41, and her husband, Mr. Sarin Ros, 47, live about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh. They were married in 1987 and have eight children; four sons and four daughters. Four of them study in local school. Two of their sons are assisting their father in driving a moto-remoque taxi and cutting grass to sell as cattle feed. One daughter is working in a garment factory. The youngest one is seven months old.

Saroeun is a housewife and takes care of her children. Closer to Phnom Penh, National Road Two is lined with garment factories. At each shift change, thousands of workers, mostly women, need to be ferried to and from the surrounding villages. Cambodians use the moto-remoque, a very economical combination of a trailer pulled by a 100 or 125cc motorbike. They typically hold as many as eighteen or more people. Saroeun is requesting a loan of US$200 to level up her house foundation.

loans.use: To level up her house foundation.

loans.name: Amen

texts.en: Amen I. sells provisions, drinks and foodstuffs. Amen and her family lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She is 49 years old and married with four children. This business has been of great support to her and her family. She requests a loan of $775 to purchase more provisions, foodstuffs and drinks to sell. She says thank you to all that make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks, provisions and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Salif

texts.fr:
C’est dans le quartier Heremakono Nord de la ville de Bougouni(troisième région administrative du Mali)que Monsieur Salif D.,  âgé de 48 ans vit avec ses  7 enfants et son épouse dans une famille nucléaire.
Après plusieurs activités génératrices de revenus sans succès, il opte d’évoluer dans le secteur de la prestation de services en l’occurrance le collage de pneus et la soudure(electrique et au chalumeau). Il a fait  un long apprentissage auprès de son oncle durant lequel il capitalisa une somme de connaissances. Avec une expérience de 10 ans Monsieur Salif D. maîtrise son activité et est très apprécié à Bougouni. Son atelier est situé sur l’artère principale  reliant Bougouni à  la préfecture de Yanfolila( frontière Guinnéenne de Conakry).
Afin de satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante décide collaborer avec le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Il est à sa premier prêt. Individuel.
Il compte acheter, 10 douzaines de baguettes, 2 pneus et 1 pompe à air à Bamako(capitale de la république du Mali) ou quelques fois sur place à Bougouni auprès des quincailliers. Sa clientèle est composée surtout de routiers et de quelques habitants de la ville.
Il espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour renforcer son entreprise.
texts.en:
The Heremakono Nord neighborhood of Bougouni (third administrative region of Mali) is where Mr. Salif D. lives. He is 48 years old and lives with his wife and seven children in a nuclear family. After several unsuccessful money-making business activities, he decided to opt specifically for providing tire fixing and welding (electric and blowtorch) services. He served a long apprenticeship with his uncle, during which he accumulated a wealth of knowledge. With 10 years’ experience, Mr. D. has mastered his craft and is highly thought of in Bougouni. His workshop is located on the main road joining Bougouni to the Yanfolila prefecture (the border with Conakry in Guinea). In order to satisfy his ever-increasing clientele he decided to get involved with the credit program run by the microfinance organization, Soro Yiriwaso – a Kiva partner. This is his first personal loan. He intends to buy 10 dozen rods, two tires and an air pump in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali) or even from the ironmongers in Bougouni itself. His clientele includes mainly truck drivers and some town residents. He hopes to make a monthly profit of 75,000 FCFA ($150) that he will use for improvements to his business.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase materials for fixing tires and for welding

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en: Patricia O. sells drinks, body creams, and other provisions from her home. She requests a loan of $700 to purchase more drinks, body creams and provisions to sell. She is 48 years old and married with 5 children. All her children are all in school. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks, provisions and body creams to sell

loans.name: Nhanh Chhum's Group

texts.en:
Nhanh C. (the first from the right) was selected to be a group leader by members for a loan from Maxima. In the group there are three families including her family. The entire group members are living along National Road Number Two, which is about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh.
1- Nhanh C., 38, and her husband, Sarim Tuy, were married in 1988 and have six children; five sons and one daughter. Two of their children are married and live outside the family home, three children attend school and the youngest one is still very young. Nhanh has been selling duck eggs for one year. Her husband has been a mason for seven years. She is requesting a loan in the amount of $300 to purchase a cow.
2-Sim H. (the second from the right), 26, is a widow with one son who is still very young. Sim has been selling second-hand clothes for four years. She bought them from a market in Phnom Penh to resell Ta Khmao market. She is requesting a loan in the amount of $300 to purchase more second-hand clothes for resale.
3-Soeun H., 29, and his wife, Sivorn Chorn, 29, were married in 1996 and have three children; two sons and one daughter. Two of them attend school and the other one is still young and stays at home. Soeurn has been a mason and fisherman for ten years. His wife has been fishing and selling for ten years as well. He is requesting a loan of $200 to purchase seine for fishing.

loans.use: To purchase cow for raising, buy clothes for resale, and for fishing.

loans.name: Bridget

texts.en: Bridget U. lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She is 40 years old and married with 4 children. Bridget sells provisions, foodstuffs and drinks. She is happy because the festive season is approaching and the demands for her goods will increase. She requests a loan of $700 to purchase more provisions, drinks and foodstuffs to sell. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions, foodstuffs and drinks to sell

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella O. sells medicines in her store. She is 39 years old and married with 4 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. Her children are both in primary and secondary school. Stella purchases medicines from Onitsha to sell in Benin City. She has good relationships with her customers and this has helped her business. She requests a $425 loan to purchase more medicines to sell. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Christy

texts.en: Christy Ensiful sells foodstuffs like yams and plantains. She purchases the foodstuffs from the village market to sell in Benin City. She and her family lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She is 43 years old and married with 3 children. The demands for her foodstuffs are high and she hopes to meet the requirements of her customers. She requests a $525 loan to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thank you to all that makethis loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Benkadi (L’Unité) Group

texts.fr:
Constitué de 6 femmes (deux veuves et quatre mariées), le groupe Benkadi de l’association Benkelema de Yangasso (préfecture de San quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali) ont en moyenne 50 ans,  5 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies avec les coépouses et autres parents. 
Elles mènent les activités d’achat et de vente des condiments alimentaires et la préparation vente des plats alimentaires.
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis deux ans. Le montant du prêt est passé de 50.000 FCFA au premier prêt à 100.000 FCFA pour le quatrième prêt et tous les précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter des sacs de riz, de haricots  (pour la restauration), des sacs d’oignons, des bidons d’huiles alimentaires  et divers condiments destinés à la vente. Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement au grand marché de Yangasso auprès des commerçants grossistes pour les condiments alimentaires et quant aux céréales sèches auprès des paysans producteurs des villages environnants.
Elles vendent les condiments alimentaires devant la porte de leur maison nuit et jour, et pour la restauration elles ont des gargotes au marché de Yangasso.
Elles comptent réaliser chacune en moyenne 100 000FCFA. de bénéfice par cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et subvenir aux dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkadi group from the Benkelema association in Yangasso (the prefecture of San - the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali) is made up of six women (two widows and four wives). On average these women are 50 years old, have five children each and live in traditional extended families with their husbands and other relatives. They buy and sell condiments, and prepare and sell meals. In order to grow their business activities, the members of the group decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva partner) loan program two years ago. The total amount borrowed has risen from 50,000 FCFA for the first loan to 100,000 FCFA for the fourth loan. All previous loans have been satisfactorily repaid. The current loan will be used to purchase sacks of rice and beans (for the catering), sacks of onions, cans of cooking oil and various condiments to sell. They buy their stock of condiments mainly from wholesalers at the large market in Yangasso and they buy the dried grains from farmers in the nearby villages. They sell the condiments in front of their houses both night and day, and for the catering they have small luncheonettes in the Yangasso market. They reckon on each making an average profit of 100,000 FCFA per cycle, which will be used to repay the loan interest and cover family expenses.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments and grain

loans.name: Norn

texts.en:
Mrs. Norn Y., 46, cultivates rice and makes Khmer Cakes that she sells in front of her house, earning a daily profit of about $2. She is married to Mr. On Srey, 48, a fisherman, and they have four children, all single, one a garment factory worker earning $75 per month.

In order to earn additional income and enlarge the business, Norn is requesting a $300 loan to purchase piglets to raise plus more ingredients and carving wood to make Khmer Cakes to sell.

loans.use: To purchase piglets for raising.

loans.name: Kimsean

texts.en:
Mrs. Kimsean Y., the 25-year-old mother of a young child, sells food, drinks, wines, and beers that her customers come to consume in her local house. Her husband, Mr. Vet On, 27, is both a goldsmith and a motorcycle taxi driver. They reside in Treal Commune, Kompong Tom Province.

In order to enlarge her business and increase her income to better provide for her family, Kimsean is requesting a loan of $350 to buy more meats and ingredients as well as a cow. She, her husband, her child and her nephew are pictured.

loans.use: To buy more meats and ingredients.

loans.name: Choun

texts.en:
Choun Y., 26, and his wife, Sreyneang Yoem, 23,  live in a small village off about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh  They were married in 2007 and have one young son.

Choun has been a truck driver for one year. He carries cows, vegetables, and other goods from his village to other places for villagers to earn a living. His wife use to work in a garment factory but now she stays at home take care of her little boy. Choun is requesting a loan of US$500 to purchase one motorbike for the family.

loans.use: To purchase one motorbike for using in the family.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence I. is a trader who sells drinks and sachets water. She purchases the drinks and sachets water from distributors in Benin City to sell to her customers. Florence is 34 years old and married with 2 children. She requests a $425 loan to purchase more drinks to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To help build a small house for her family

loans.name: Osasere

texts.en: Osasere Amadsun is 38 years old and married with 3 children. She sells sarongs and female clothing. She is a LAPO client. With the little profit coming from her business she is able to contribute to her family upkeep. She hopes to expand her business. She requests a $425 loan to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thank you to all that make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Leang

texts.en:
Leang C., 31, and her husband, Vuthy Sem, 39, who live in a small village about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1993 and have four daughters. One of their daughters is a garment factory worker, two daughters attend school and the fourth is still too young to attend. Beside their children, her father also lives with them.
Leang is a housewife. Her husband (not pictured) has been driving a motorbike taxi in Phnom Penh for about ten years. Prior to that, he was a “cyclo,” or bicycle taxi, driver. Motorbike taxis are by far the most common form of transportation in Phnom Penh. Leang’s husband leaves their house at 4:00 A.M. and returns around 6:00 P.M. In a typical day he makes about 20,000 Riel (US $5.00). Leang is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase a cow for raising.

loans.use: To purchase cow for raising.

loans.name: Pov

texts.en: Mrs. Pov S. is a villager in Prey Ta Kap village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land for cultivating rice. Because she has to hire a laborer to plow her field, she is requesting a loan to buy two oxen for breeding and plowing. This will reduce her expenses and increase her earnings. Her husband, Mr. Rim Ry, is a construction worker. Mrs. Pov S. is 27 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is attending the local school. Her husband is shown on the right of photo.

loans.use: To purchase two oxen for breeding and plowing

loans.name: Benkadi (L’Unité) Group

texts.fr:
Benkadi  est un regroupement de 10  femmes toutes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans et  4  enfants. Vivant dans des familles polygames avec les beaux parents, et autres parents du conjoint, elles résident dans le village de Yangasso de la préfecture de San(quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
L’activité dominante de ce groupe est la cuisson et la vente de farine de blé et des beignets de haricot. Dans le souci de satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elles ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis deux ans. Après voir correctement remboursée les trois premiers prêts, elles sont à leur quatrième prêt de groupe.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, des sacs de farine de blé,  de haricot et des bidons d’huiles alimentaires auprès des grossistes du grand marché de Yangasso. Elles effectuent leurs ventes aux abords de l’artère principale du village à une clientèle composée essentiellement de routiers en détail et surtout au comptant. 
Ainsi avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent réaliser en moyenne 110 000FCFA. de bénéfice par cycle qu’elles utiliser pour payer les intérêts du prêt et investir le reste dans les activités. Dans un futur proche elles ambitionnent diversifier les plats alimentaires cuisinés.
texts.en:
Benkadi is a group of 10 women, all married and with an average age of 30 and, on average, 4 children. Living in polygamous families with parents-in-law and other relatives of their husbands, they reside in the village of Yangasso in the prefecture of San (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

The main business of this group is the cooking and sale of wheat flour and bean fritters. In the interest of satisfying the demand of their ever-growing clientele, they decided to join the credit program of Soro Yiriwaso two years ago. After having correctly reimbursed their first three loans, they are now on their fourth group loan.

This loan will be used to buy sacks of wheat flour, dried beans, and jerry cans of cooking oil from the wholesalers of the big open-air market of Yangasso. They sell their food by the side of the main road of the village to a clientele composed essentially of truckers and travelers, retail and mostly for cash.

Thus, with this new loan, they expect to make an average of 110,000 F CFA in profit per cycle which they will use to make payments on the loan, investing any remainder in their businesses. In the near future their ambition is to diversify the dishes that they cook for sale.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of raw materials for food service

loans.name: Sonak

texts.en:
Sonak S., 28, lives on an Island of Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. She is married and has three children; two sons and one daughter. All of them are still young. Her mother also lives with her family.
 
Sonak has been a silk weaver for ten years, which is a skill she learned from her mother when she was thirteen years old. Her husband is a silk weaver as well. They sell their finished products to the middle man in the village, who then takes it to resell in Phnom Penh. Sonak is requesting a loan of $200 to purchase additional silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for weaving business.

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en: Deborah G. lives in Benin City. She sells foodstuffs, drinks and provisions. Deborah is a LAPO client. She is 48 years old and married with 4 children. She requests a $425 loan to purchase more drinks, provisions and foodstuffs to sell. She says thank you to all that make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions, foodstuffs and drinks to sell

loans.name: Sambou

texts.en: Mrs. Sambou K. is a villager in Ou Sngoeun village in Takeo Province. She and her husband, Mr. Kann Samoeurn, are farmers who own a piece of land where they cultivate rice. T In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Sambou K. is requesting a loan to buy four piglets and pig food to start a pig-breeding business. She is 47 years old and the mother of eight children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the others are attending the local school.

loans.use: To purchase pigs and pig food to start a pig-breeding business

loans.name: Muhammad

texts.en:
Muhammad A. is an uneducated man who works in agriculture. He lives in a household of 9 members, including his brother's family. A. is 70 years old and he lives in Nangrahar. He has been involved in agriculture for more than 10 years. He used to be able to support his two families well but things are not very good now. He is faced with lots of economic difficulties in his family, so he wants to expand his business.

He needs money here to expand his business to help these two families. He wants to take out an individual loan to complete his seed stock and ready all his land for cultivation, to work hard and make a better income to support his family.

He is happy about this loan. He would like to thank Kiva and the lenders that make these opportunities possible in this poor country where people are faced with lots of problems. He hopes to be successful in his business in the future.

loans.use: To complete his stock

loans.name: Sophear

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophea Y., a 33-year-old mother of three children in Chouksach Commune, Kompong Tom Province, has been growing rice since 1999. She is married to Mr. Eung Him, 29, a horse taxi driver who earns a daily income of about $3.

To earn additional profits and better provide for her family, Sophea is applying for a $300 loan to buy piglets to raise and to replace an old horse.

loans.use: To buy piglets to raise.

loans.name: Sokha

texts.en: Mrs. Sokha C. is 36 years old, a widow and lives in Ang Kounh village in Takeo Province. She is a cake seller in the local school. Mrs. Sokha C. is requesting a loan to buy a motorbike which will enable her to transport her merchandise herself and save on transportation costs. Reducing her expenses will increase her profit. Also, she can hire out to help others with transportation. She has four children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the others are enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for transportation.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence A. is 41 years old and married with 5 children. She sells foodstuffs, provisions, and drinks. She has been in this business for a long time. The demands for her goods are high. Florence lives in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria. She requests a $525 loan to purchase more provisions, drinks, and foodstuffs to sell. She says thank you to all that make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions, foodstuffs and drinks to sell

loans.name: Osas

texts.en: Osas I. lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She is 28 years old and married with a child. She sells provisions, drinks, and foodstuffs. She started this business in 2007. She requests a $425 loan to purchase more provisions, drinks, and foodstuffs to sell. She says thank you to all that make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions, foodstuffs, and drinks to sell

loans.name: Koem Heng

texts.en: Mrs. Koem Heng C. is 49 years old and lives in Ou Sngoeun village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who earns income growing rice and different types of vegetables. She is requesting a loan to buy six piglets and pig food. Adding pig breeding to her farming will increase her income and improve her living conditions. She is the mother of two children who are employed in a garment factory.

loans.use: To purchase pigs and pig food to start a pig-breeding business

loans.name: Seyha

texts.en:
Seyha M., 32, and his wife, Sophy Phal, 25, live about seventeen Kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 2002 and have two daughters. Their eldest daughter attends primary school.

Seyha has been a truck driver in a garment factory near his village for four years. His wife is a housewife and raises cows in the village. Seyha is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase one cow for his wife and some to pay school fees for his brother who studies at the University in Phnom Penh.

loans.use: To purchase a cow for raising and some to help pay school fees for his brother.

loans.name: Khom

texts.en:
Mr. Khom U., 27, and his wife, Mrs. Puthy Mao, 27, were married in 2004 and have two daughters. Their youngest daughter is 7 months old. Khom and his wife are living at National Road Number Six about twenty Kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Khom has been a construction contractor since 2000. His wife stays at home taking care of their daughters. Khom is requesting a loan of $500 to pay for workers fees in his construction business.

loans.use: To pay for workers fees.

loans.name: Khun

texts.en: Mrs. Khun L. is a villager in Ang Kounh village in Takeo Province. She is a chicken breeder. Her husband, Mr. Poeuv Yos, is a farmer who owns a plot of land where he grows rice. Mrs. Khun L. is requesting a loan to buy wood for building a house for her family. She is 52 years old and the mother of two children who are enrolled in the local school. The new house will improve her family's standard of living, and because they both work, the loan will be repaid on schedule.

loans.use: To purchase wood for a new family house

loans.name: Onyekachi

texts.en: Onyekachi O. owns a store where he sells rechargeable phones and phones accessories. He is 27 years old and single. He hopes to get married soon. Onyekachi travels to Lagos and Onitsha to purchase rechargeable phones and phone accessories to sell in Benin City. He requests a $275 loan to purchase more rechargeable phones and accessories. He says thank you to all that make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more rechargeable phones and phone accessories to sell

loans.name: Philomena

texts.en: Philomena A. is 67 years old and a widow with 2 children. She sells provisions, drinks, and pure water. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She requests a $275 loan to purchase more provisions, drinks, and foodstuffs to sell. She says thank you to all that make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions, drinks, and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Norn

texts.en: Mrs. Norn B. is a villager in Ou Sngoeun village in Takeo Province. She owns a small restaurant. Her husband, Mr. Nget Bol, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where he grows rice. Mrs. Norn B. is requesting a loan to buy three piglets and pig food to start a pig-breeding business. She hopes to increase income and improve her living conditions with this new enterprise. She is 31 years old and the mother of three children, two of whom are attending the local school while the other is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To purchase pigs and pig food to start a pig-breeding business

loans.name: Boret

texts.en:
Mr. Boret C., 27, was married in 2006 and has one daughter. He and his wife live with his parents on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Boret has been a silk weaver for two years, a skill he learned from his sister. His wife used to be a garment factory worker but now she stays at home taking care of her little daughter. Boret sells his finished product to the middle man in the village, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh. He is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase silk materials and to set up a loom for a weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials and set up a loom for a weaving business.

loans.name: You

texts.en:
Mr. You K., 43, and Mrs. Las Yom, 40, live on an island in Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1993 and have six children: four sons and two daughters. Five of their children attend school and the youngest one stays at home.

Mr. You and his wife have been farmers for over ten years. Currently, they grow corn and tomatoes on their farmland. Besides farming, Mr. You is a mason and does fishing as well, while his wife also raises pigs. They sell their yield to a middleman who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh. Mr. You is requesting a loan of $400 to purchase fertilizers and pesticides, and to pay fees for workers for his farming business.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and pesticides, and to pay fees for workers for his farming business.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty Aiguopbarueghian sells second-hand clothes and sarongs in the New Benin Market. This is one of the busiest markets in Benin City. She purchases the second-hand clothes from Lagos to sell in Benin City. Betty is 54 years old and married with 6 children. She requests a $425 loan to purchase more second-hand clothes to sell. She says thank you to all that make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more second-hand clothes to sell

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Mrs. Chan L. is a villager in Ang village in Kandal Province. She and her husband, Mr. Ky Lok, are farmers who own a piece of land where they grow rice. There field has several problems. The soil is infertile because it has been worked so much, and they need money for rice and to hire a laborer to plow. Mrs. Chan L. is requesting a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizer, pesticides, and to hire a labor with an electric cow to plow the field. She hopes to increase income and improve her family's living conditions.She is 44 years old and the mother of three, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the other is attending the local school.

loans.use: To purchase rice seed, fertilizer, pesticides, and to hire a labor with an electric cow to plow the field.

loans.name: Simut

texts.en:
Mrs. Simut O., 27, and her husband, Mr. Sophea Hout, 34, live on an island on Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1993 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. All of their children study in a local school.

Mrs. Simut and her husband have been selling fish since 2005. They buy them from a fishing lot at Prek Phnao village, about twenty kilometers from their village, for resale in the village market. Simut is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase more fish to increase the volume of fish sales.

loans.use: To purchase fish for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more children’s clothes and shoes to sell

loans.name: Vun

texts.en:
Mr. Vun K., 60, and his wife, Mrs. Oeung Van, 58, live along national road number one about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1970 and have seven children: four sons and three daughters. Four of their children are married and live outside the family home. One child is a garment factory worker, another child does farming and the youngest one studies in a local school.

Mr. Vun and his wife have been farming since 1988. They grow many types of crops and vegetables on their farmland. Currently, the couple grows corn on their farm. Mr. Vun is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase fertilizer, corn seed and pesticide for his farm.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, pesticide and fertilizer for their farming business.

loans.name: Djekadi (L’Union Est Bonne Group

texts.fr:
Résidant toutes dans le village de Yangasso préfecture de San (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali) dans des familles traditionnelles élargies, les six femmes du groupe Djekadi de l’association Siguidia ont une moyenne d’âge de 45 ans et 6 enfants.  Unies par des liens professionnels et de voisinage, elles se sont spécialisées dans la fabrication et la vente de pain.
Elles collaborent avec le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance de Soro Yiriwaso depuis deux ans. Le montant du prêt est passé de 50.000 FCFA au premier prêt à 75.000 FCFA pour le quatrième prêt. Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, des sacs de farine de blé destinés à la fabrication du pain. 
Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Yangasso dans les boutiques. Elles effectuent leur vente dans le même marché  et à la maison où elles ont leur four traditionnel implanté. La vente est effectuée à une clientèle constituée de toutes les catégories sociales du village. 
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent réaliser chacune en moyenne 60 000FCFA. de bénéfice par cycle qui sera utilisé pour les dépenses courantes de la famille. Elles ambitionnent ouvrir une boulangerie moderne à Yangasso.
texts.en:
All residents of the village of Yangasso in the prefecture of San (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali) and living in traditional extended families, the six women of the Djekadi group of the Siguidia Assocation are on average 45 and have, on average 6 children. United by professional bonds and the ties of neighborhood, they are specialized in baking and selling bread.

They have been a part of the credit program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso for two years now. The amount of their loans has gone from 50,000 F CFA for their first loan to 75,000 F CFA for their fourth. The present loan will be used to buy sacks of wheat flour for bread making.

They buy their supplies in the market of Yangasso in the little shops there. They sell in the same market and at home where their traditional oven is located. Their sales are made to a clientele constituted of all sorts of people from their village.

With this new loan, they each expect to make an average of 60,000 F CFA of profit per cycle, which will be used for everyday expenditures in their families. Their ambition is to open a modern bakery in Yangasso.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of wheat flour

loans.name: Sinat

texts.en:
Mrs. Sinat S., a 25-year-old mother of one living in Ptasrong Commune, Pursat Province, grows and sells rice and vegetables for a living. She is married to Mr. Pros Phon, 26, a status carver since 2001.

Sinat is now requesting a loan of $500 to purchase more wood for her husband’s business and fertilizer for her rice crop. Mrs. Sinat's husband is pictured because she was not available.

loans.use: To purchase more wood and fertilizer.

loans.name: Christy

texts.en: Christy A. is 38 years old and married with a child. She sells yams. The demands for her yam are high. She hopes to expand her business so that she can have more customers. She requests a $350 loan to purchase more yams to sell. She says thank you to all that make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more yams to sell

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en: Caroline O. sells clothes in Evbareke market in Benin City, Nigeria. She has been in the clothing business for a long time. The demands for her clothing are high and with the holiday season approaching, she expects the demand to increase. She is 40 years old and married with 4 children. She needs a loan of N50,000 ($425) to purchase more clothes to sell. She says thank you to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Jiguisèmè (L’Espoir) Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Jiguisèmè toutes des voisines et évoluant dans le même secteur économique, résident dans le village de Yangasso (préfecture de San quatrième région administrative du Mali). Elles ont en moyenne 30 ans et 4 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles avec les coépouses, les beaux parents et autres parents du conjoint.
Depuis maintenant deux ans elles collaborent avec le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso lequel leur a déjà octroyer trois prêts de groupe tous correctement remboursés. Avec ce quatrième elles comptent acheter, des habits, des parures à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) et Koutiala auprès des grossistes du domaine. Quant aux chaussures elles sont importées du Burkuna Faso. 
Elles effectuent leurs ventes au marché et de façon ambulante dans le village, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle constituée essentiellement de femmes. Chacune des membres de ce groupe espèrent réaliser en moyenne 100 000FCFA. de bénéfice cycle qui sera utilisé pour subvenir aux dépenses de la famille. Elles ambitionnent ouvrir une boutique à Yangasso.
texts.en:
The four women of the Jiguisèmè group, all of them neighbors and coming from the same economic sector, live in the village of Yangasso (prefecture of San, fourth administrative region of Mali). They have an average age of 30 and, on average, 4 children, and they live in traditional families with their co-spouses, parents-in-law, and other relatives of their husbands.

For two years now they have been working with the credit program of Soro Yiriwaso which has already given them three group loans which have been correctly reimbursed. With their fourth loan, they intend to buy clothing and costume jewelry in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali) and in Koutiala from wholesalers who sell these sorts of goods. As for shoes, those are imported from Burkina Faso.

They do their selling in the market and door-to-door in the village, for cash or credit, to a clientele constituted essentially of women. Each of the members of the group hopes to make an average of 100,000 F CFA of profit per cycle, which will be used to help cover family expenses. Their ambition is to open a little shop in Yangasso.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of clothing, costume jewelry, and shoes for re-sale

loans.name: Zauja

texts.en:
N. Zauja operates a class C drug shop at the Bwole taxi park in the district of Bugiri. As she must now replenish her stock, she will use the loan to purchase additional antibiotics, quinine, chloroquine, omeprazol, nancoprazol and other items.

Manmaganda is happily married and has 3 children, ages 6-10. Her children attend primary school within the district. Her business enables her to give her husband a hand in providing for the family's needs. Her greatest ambition is to operate a class A drug shop, that would be licensed to sell all types of drugs. That would definitely result in a positive impact to her income. With this future prospect, she hopes to offer her family a better standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase additional antibiotics, quinine, chloroquine, omeprazol, nancoprazol and other items.

loans.name: Yun

texts.en:
Mrs. Yun S., 56, and her husband, Mr. Ngoun Tor, 46, live along national road number one about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1992 and have four children: two sons and two daughters. All of them study in a local school.

Yun and her husband have been farming for five years. Currently, they grow cauliflowers on their farmland. She is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticide to use on her cauliflower farm.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticide for using on her farm.

loans.name: Komi

texts.en: Komi A. is 35 years old and a married father. He lives and works in the village of Wome, a small village located in a beautiful, lush area of Togo near the border with Ghana. Komi’s children all attend school, and he provides for them as best he can, while his wife takes care of the family and their home. As most people do not drive cars in Wome and instead drive motorcycles, Komi started a mechanical business. As seen in this photo, Komi buys used motorcycles and parts and puts them together again, in order to then sell the new, improved motorcycles. With this loan from Kiva, Komi looks forward to expanding his business and the space in which he works so that he may better serve his ever-growing clientele. He thanks Kiva for the opportunity to improve the quality of life for his family.

loans.use: To expand his business and the space in which he works

loans.name: Alliton

texts.en: Alliton O. sells mobile phone accessories, rechargeable phone cards, and access to make phone calls. After completing secondary school, he decided to go into the phone business. He needs a loan of N50,000 ($425) to purchase more rechargeable phone cards and accessories to sell. He is 27 years old and single. He says thank you to all.

loans.use: To purchase more phone cards and accessories to sell

loans.name: Maleïka (Nom D’Une Personne Honoré) Group

texts.fr:
Constitué de cinq femmes mariées vivant dans des familles nucléaires  avec leurs maris et leurs enfants dans le quartier Koko de la préfecture de Koutiala(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali), le groupe Maleika a une moyenne de 35 ans et 4 enfants.
L’activité dominante de ces femmes qui se sont connues par des relations d’alliances et de parenté est essentiellement la vente du bois de chauffe. Elles sont en relation avec le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis trois ans. Le montant du prêt est passé de 50.000 FCFA au premier à 100.000 FCFA pour le sixième.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter un stock important de bois de chauffe. Elles s’approvisionnent auprès des paysans ayant une autorisation de coupe dans les villages environnants de la ville de Koutiala. Ensuite à bord de camions 10 tonnes elles acheminent leurs marchandises qui seront vendues en détail au comptant quelques fois à crédit aux ménagères et aux revendeurs.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent réaliser en moyenne 100 000 CFA. de bénéfice par  cycle. En dehors du remboursement des prêts, elles utiliseront une partie du revenu  pour les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Made up of five married women who live in nuclear families with their spouses and children in the Koko neighborhood of the prefecture of Koutiala (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali), the Maleika group has an average age of 35 with 4 children.

The primary business activity of these women who met through relatives and in-laws is essentially selling firewood. They have been members of the credit program of Soro Yiriwaso for three years. The amount of their loans has gone from 50,000 F CFA for the first to 100,000 F CFA for their sixth.

This loan will be used to buy a big supply of firewood. They buy it from rural people who have a permit to cut wood in the villages surrounding the town of Koutiala. Then they use 10-ton trucks to transport the wood which will be sold retail and on a cash basis, or sometimes on credit, to housewives and other retailers.

With this loan they expect to make on average 100,000 F CFA in profit per cycle. Apart from the reimbursement of the loan, they will use a part of the income for everyday expenses of their families.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of firewood for re-sale

loans.name: Rat

texts.en:
Mrs. Rat C., of Lvengreusey Commune, Siem Reap Province, is a 37-year-old rice farmer and the mother of two children, both students. Her husband, Mr. Bing Ngorn, 32, has been a fisherman since 2005, earning approximately $6 per day.

Mrs. Rat is requesting a $1,000 loan to buy rice seed and fertilizers and to pay for the plowing of her farmland.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and fertilizers.

loans.name: Som-Oeun

texts.en:
Mr. Som-oeun M., 45, and his wife, Mrs. Savet Bau, 44, who live along National Road Number One about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1981 and have four children: two sons and two daughters. One daughter is fully employed and two children are in school and help them in the business when they are free from their studies. The youngest one stays at home.

Som-oeun and his wife have been selling fruit for five years. They buy mangoes, sapodillas, and other fruits from farmers in the village and sell them at a market in Phnom Penh. The couple needs to pay money to the farmers first before harvest season that they can buy at a cheaper price. Therefore, Som-oeun is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase fruits in contract for resale.

loans.use: To purchase fruits in contract for resale.

loans.name: Parviz

texts.en:
Parviz Z. is 22 years old. He is a young hairdresser who works in the barber shop in a small village in the southern part of Azerbaijan. He started his business in 2006, after getting an education in this field. Parviz is married and lives with his parents, who are on pension now.  

Parviz works very hard because his income from this business is the sole financial source for his family. Parviz is very polite with his clients--that’s why his place is always full of people.  He starts his working day at 9 in the morning and finishes at 11 at night. Parviz rents a place and pays monthly rent, and he must finance all changes and improvements himself. 

Parviz would like to expand his business and purchase modern tools for hairdressing, so he applied for a loan of 1200 USD. Parviz is very excited to implement new tools in his business so he can attract more clients and increase his income. Parviz's wife is expecting a child, so Parviz is working even harder than usual to cover all the needs of the new baby. Parviz and his family appreciate your support very much!

loans.use: Purchase new tools for hairdressing

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James K.  is married and has 6 children between ages 20-25. The four eldest children and employed and the younger two are in high school. He operates a wooden furniture business and the income has enabled his children to attend school. His workshop is located along the Gabula road, in the Kitimbo zone. 

Due to an increase in his customer base, James is requesting a loan that would allow him increase his stock of timber, paints, nails, vanishes, and other items. By promptly meeting his customers demands, tastes and preferences, he will be able to earn a considerable amount of profit.  Some of this profit will be reinvested into the business to expand his workshop. He aspires to maintain and keep his family healthy.

loans.use: Increase his supplies of timber, paints, nails, vanishes and other items.

loans.name: Siguidia (Fait Bon De Vivre) Group

texts.fr:
Les 4 femmes du  groupe Siguidia (deux mariées, une veuve et une célibataire) avec une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans et 3 enfants, vivent dans des familles nucléaires avec leurs maris ou leurs  enfants dans le quartier Koko de la préfecture de Koutiala(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Se connaissant mutuellement depuis de longues dates et monitrices au jardin d’enfants communal de Koutiala, elles font également la teinture,  la vente de bazins et de parures. Elles font des expositions à plusieurs foires artistiques et culturelles de la région de Sikasso, d’autres localités du Mali et quelques fois à l’extérieur du pays. 
Compte tenu de l’évolution de leurs activités, la nécessité d’une assistance financière s’imposa, alors elles rejoignirent l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso, depuis maintenant six ans.
Le montant du prêt est passé de 50.000 FCFA au premier à 150.000 FCFA  par personne pour ce onzième prêt qui sera utilisé pour acheter un stock important d’indigos de bois de chauffe et des balles de bazin  pour la teinture. Elles se procurent de leurs marchandises à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali). Les produits finis sont vendus à la maison et au lieu de travail au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle essentiellement composée de femmes.
Elles comptent réaliser en moyenne 150 000FCFA. de bénéfice par cycle qui servira en plus du remboursement des intérêts du prêt, à subvenir aux dépenses de la famille et investir le reste dans les affaires.  Dans les jours à venir les membres du groupe comptent ouvrir une boutique de vente d’indigo à Koutiala.
texts.en:
The four women of the Siguidia group (two married, one widowed, and one still single) have an average age of 40 and 3 children. They live in nuclear families with their families, spouses, or children in the Koko neighborhood of the prefecture of Koutiala (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Having known each other for a long time and as teachers in the communal kindergarten of Koutiala, they have businesses in dyeing, sale of "bazin" (damask cloth), and costume jewelry. They have displayed their wares in several artistic and cultural fairs in the Sikasso region, in other localities in Mali, and sometimes outside the country.

Taking into consideration the evolution of their businesses, they felt the necessity of financial aid, so they joined the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, 6 years ago.

The amount they are allowed to borrow has grown from 50,000 F CFA for their first loan to 150,000 F CFA per person for this 11th loan which will be used to buy large quantities of indigo, firewood, and bales of "bazin" cloth for dyeing. They buy their supplies in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali). The finished products are sold from their homes and in workplaces for cash or on credit to a clientele essentially composed of women.

They expect to make an average of 150,000 F CFA in profit per cycle which will be used to reimburse the loan and to cover family expenses, with any remainder invested in their businesses. In the coming days, the members of the group intend to open a boutique to sell indigo in Koutiala.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of raw materials for dyeing cloth

loans.name: Nestor

texts.en: Nestor D. is a 22-year-old single man living in Wome, Togo, a small village located approximately 130 miles from the capital, Lomé. Nestor has an entrepreneurial spirit and has taken over his parents’ general store. His sister, also pictured, works with him when she is not in school. Nestor’s shop stocks everything from cooking oil and canned goods to soap and prepaid cellphone cards. With this loan from Kiva, Nestor hopes to increase the variety of items in his inventory and improve the appearance of his shop, to draw in more customers. With the money he will earn from increased business, Nestor can contribute to the school fees of his younger siblings, as well as save money for his future.

loans.use: To increase the variety of items in his inventory and improve the appearance of his shop

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet M., 35 years old, is a loving and caring mother of four. Her children are between the ages of 10-15 years. She runs a retail shop that offers a variety of utensils and plastic ware in the Buwenge market zone. She has been successfully operating this business for over 5 years.  Juliet is hard working and determined. She is requesting this loan to purchase additional saucepans, basins, plates, buckets, flasks, glasses, cups, jerrycans and other items.  

Juliet hopes that the profits from this business will enable her to educate her children and also achieve her dream of operating on a wholesale basis, offering utensils and plastic ware, sourced from various manufacturers around the globe.

loans.use: Purchase additional supplies of saucepans, basins, plates, buckets, flasks, glasses, cups, jerrycans and other items.

loans.name: Glory

texts.en:
Glory A. sells provisions and drinks. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes to expand her business by stocking her shop with products her customers need. She is 36 years old and married with 3 children. She needs a loan of N60,000 to purchase more drinks and provisions to sell. 
She says thank you to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase drinks and provisions to sell

loans.name: Tièssiri  (Courage) Group

texts.fr:
Tièssiri  est un regroupement de 4  femmes  qui se connaissent bien. Elles vivent dans des foyers polygames dans le village de Yangasso préfecture de San (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali) et ont en moyenne 40 ans, mariées et mères d’au moins 4  enfant.
Elles mènent  une même activité à savoir la préparation et vente de Jouga (un couscous  qui se fait à base de fonio et d’arachide) très prisé par la population locale.
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis deux ans. Le montant du prêt est passé de 50.000 FCFA au premier prêt à 125.000 FCFA pour le quatrième prêt.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, des sacs de fonio et d’arachide auprès des paysans producteurs des villages  environnants et sur place au marché de Yangasso les jours de foire. Elles préparent à domicile leur plat et effectuent leur vente aux abords de l’école où les élèves et les enseignants pendant les heures de récréation et de pauses viennent s’y restaurer. Elles comptent réaliser chacune en moyenne 150 000FCFA. de bénéfice par cycle. Dans l’avenir elles envisagent ouvrir une cantine scolaire.
texts.en:
Tièssiri is a group of 4 women who know each other well. They live in polygamous households in the village of Yangasso, prefecture of San (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali) and are on average 40 years old, married, and mothers of at least 4 children.

They each have the same business, namely the preparation and sale of "jouga", a couscous that is made out of "fonio" (a kind of millet) and peanuts, a dish very highly prized by the local population.

To expand the size of their businesses, the members decided to join the credit program of Soro Yiriwaso two years ago. The amount of their loans has grown from 50,000 F CFA in the beginning to 125,000 F CFA for their fourth loan.

This loan will be used to buy sacks of "fonio" and of peanuts from the rural producers in surrounding villages and right in Yangasso on market days. They prepare the couscous in their homes and sell it near the school where the pupils and teachers come to eat it during recess and other break-times. They each expect to make on average 150,000 F CFA in profit per cycle. In future they plan to open a school lunch room.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of fonio and peanuts

loans.name: Yann

texts.en:
Mrs. Yann H., 44, who sells groceries in her home in Kompongkdey Commune, Siem Reap Province, is married to Mr. Roueng Chok, 45, a fisherman. They have three children, two of whom are students while the third is a construction worker currently earning an income of $2 per day.

Yann is now seeking a loan of $150 to purchase more groceries to sell. Her husband and daughter are pictured because she was not available.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Shahin

texts.en:
Shahin A. is a 33-year-old trader who sells men's suits in a place he rents in the southern city of Saatli. Shahin has eight years of experience in selling men's clothes. He is very polite with his clients, and during his years of experience, he has gained the respect of his clients and attracted a number of permanent clients who always purchase their clothes from Shahin.

Shahin is married and has 3 sons. His store provides the only financial income for his family. He would like to expand his business, so he has applied for a loan of 1200 USD. Shahin and his family appreciate your help.

loans.use: Purchase more men's suits

loans.name: Dilrabo

texts.en: Dilrabo G. lives in Khujand. She is 36 years old, and has 2 children. She applied for her first loan from MicroInvest in 2005. Thanks to her loans, she was able to start her business practically from scratch. Before taking out the loans from MicroInvest, she sold small wares but now she has an outlet in the local bazaar where she sells children's wear. She buys her goods from the Kyrgyz Republic and sells them in Khujand. She has been selling children's wear for 6 years now. The income from her permanent business helped her to increase the loan payments. She is a reliable and executive client. She has a good assortment of children's wear, but now she wants to import new seasonal wear to sell in Khujand.

loans.use: To increase the assortment of children's wear for sale

loans.name: Nizami

texts.en:
Nizami M. is 40-year-old farmer who breeds sheep in the small village of Sabirabad City. Nizami has 13 years of experience in sheep breeding. He purchases lambs at a low price, feeds them, and after 3-6 months, sells them in the local livestock bazaar for a higher price.

Nizami is married and has a daughter. He also works at a school as a teacher, but his main source of income is sheep breeding. Nizami has applied for a loan of 1200 USD to purchase 15 sheep and the fodder they need (the approximate price for one sheep is 70-80 USD).

loans.use: Purchase 15 sheep and fodder

loans.name: Djénéba

texts.fr:
Madame Djénéba  S. est âgée  de 60 ans et vit avec son mari et ses 6 enfants dans le quartier Pelengana Sébénikoro de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas été à  l’école pour des raisons sociales, elle commença très tôt les activités génératrices de revenus auprès de sa mère. Elle opta pour la grillade de l’arachide et l’achat vente du mil depuis maintenant 10 ans. 

Pour griller l’arachide elle met dans une poêle du sable et de l’arachide la dessus et le tout sur du feu. Avec une louche, elle remue incessamment  l’ensemble durant quelques dizaines de minutes jusqu'à ce qu’elle se rende compte que la chaleur du sable a bien grillée les grains d’arachide.

En vue de satisfaire sa clientèle plus en plus croissante elle a fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso, depuis 3 ans. Après 4 prêts solidaires et 2 prêts individuels tous correctement bien remboursés, elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel. 
Ce  nouveau prêt servira  à acheter,  15kg sacs d’arachide et 10 sacs de mil auprès des producteurs des villages environnants de Ségou.
Madame  Djénéba  S. effectue ses ventes au marché château de Ségou et dans les différentes foires (lundi de Ségou et jeudi de Banankoro), au comptant en détail à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et  de femmes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 37 500, qui servira à rembourser les intérêts du prêt et à supporter certaines charges familiales. Son ambition est de constituer un trousseau de mariage pour ses enfants.
texts.en:
Mrs. Djénéba S., 60, lives with her husband and her six children in the Pelengana Sébénikoro neighborhood of the town of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Having not been able to attend school for family reasons, she began early on to earn her living helping her mother. She chose to roast peanuts and sell millet, which she has been doing for 10 years now.

To roast the peanuts, she puts sand in a skillet and peanuts on the sand, then puts the skillet on the fire. With a ladle, she stirs continuously for a good many minutes, until she can tell that the heat of the sand has roasted the peanuts correctly.

Wishing to satisfy the needs of her ever-growing clientele, she turned to the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. After four group (solidarity) loans and two individual loans, all correctly reimbursed, she is now on her third individual loan.

This new loan will be used to buy 15 sacks of peanuts and 10 sacks of millet from the farmers in the villages around Ségou. Mrs. Djénéba S. makes her sales in the Château market in Ségou and in the various fairs (on Monday in Ségou and Thursday in Banankoro), retail and for cash or credit, to a clientele composed of men and women.

She expects to make a monthly profit of 37,500 F CFA, which will be used to make repayments on the loan and to cover certain family expenses. Her dream is to get together a trousseau for each of her children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of peanuts and millet

loans.name: Zuleykha

texts.en:
Zuleykha A. is a 53-year-old woman who breeds calves in the small village of Sabirabad City. She has been in the livestock business since her youth, and she is very experienced in this field, thanks to her father-in-law and her husband. She purchases baby calves, feeds them, and after 4-5 months, sells them for a higher price. Zuleykha wakes up early in the morning to feed her calves and spends the day looking after them. Her husband helps her, and he is the one who takes the calves to the livestock bazaar to be sold.

Zuleykha is married and has 3 children. Because she and her husband are unemployed, selling calves is the only source of income for their family. Zuleykha would like to expand her business by purchasing more calves for breeding, so she has applied for a loan of 1200 USD. She will buy three calves and fodder.

loans.use: Purchase three calves and fodder

loans.name: Rasul

texts.en:
Rasul R., age 49, has run his own food store in the small village of Sabirabad City since 1998. Rasul has 10 years of experience in selling foodstuffs. Rasul is married and has three children who all study at school.

Unemployment and financial hardship pushed Rasul to start a business by opening his store. Now he is doing well and his store brings him a stable income. Rasul is also a farmer and keeps livestock. Rasul successfully repaid his first loan. Now he would like a new loan to purchase more foodstuffs, such as cookies, candies, sugar, and macaroni.

loans.use: Purchase more food for his store

loans.name: Phalla

texts.en:
Mrs. Phalla P., 41, and her husband, Mr. Ly Nao, 37, who live along national road number one about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1990 and have five children: three sons and two daughters. One of them is married and lives outside the family house, one son sells cassette tapes, another son is a worker and the other two children attend the local school.

Mrs. Phalla and her husband have been selling Phak Lov (a famous Cambodian meal cooked with pork) since 2006. They buy the pork and other ingredients from the Koky market to cook at their home, and then sell in the village. Mrs. Phalla is requesting a loan to purchase a motorbike and cart for carrying their food to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike and cart for carrying food to sell.

loans.name: Khanoglan

texts.en:
Khanoglan H. is 47-year-old trader who sells food in the Internally Displaced Settlement of Bilasuvar City. He started his business in 1994 and it has been the sole source of income for his family ever since.

Khanoglan is married and has 2 sons. He has applied for a loan of 1200 USD to invest in more inventory to expand his grocery business.

loans.use: Purchase more food for his store

loans.name: Chap

texts.en:
Mrs. Chap C., a resident of Koktlokroam Commune, Siem Reap Province, is a 47-year-old farmer specializing in rice and vegetables while her husband, Mr. Noeun Dom, 55, has been a fisherman for about four years. They have six children: one is married; two help their father's business, and the other three are still young.

Chap is applying for a $1,000 loan to purchase two oxen to facilitate the plowing of her farm. She and her husband are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To purchase two oxen for her farm.

loans.name: Oqtay

texts.en:
Oqtay H. is a 42-year-old farmer who sells calves for meat production. He lives in the Internally Displaced Settlement of Bilasuvar City with his wife and four children.

Oqtay purchases baby calves at a low price, feeds them for 4-5 months, and then sells them to the local bazaar traders. He wakes up early in the morning and spends his whole day looking after the calves. Oqtay started his business in 1994 when financial hardship pushed him to start a business. Now he is applying for a loan of 1200 USD to purchase three calves and fodder. Your generosity will be very helpful.

loans.use: Purchase three calves and fodder

loans.name: Shirkhan

texts.en:
Shirkhan Q. is a good father and a hard-working farmer who is steadfast in his endeavor of raising animals. Shirkhan sells dairy products, such as milk and yoghurt, in addition to selling calves for meat production. He started his business in 2000 and it has been the main source of income for his family ever since. His family consists of his wife, one son, and his old parents. Thanks to his wife’s assistance, he is able to raise and feed the animals and prepare them for sale at the marketplaces in a nearby town.

In addition to raising animals, Shirkah has a car and sometimes takes local people to the downtown area for a price, but this job is not constant, so he is focused more on developing his livestock business. He is requesting a loan in the amount of 1200 USD to purchase two calves and one milking cow. He promises to be responsible and prompt in repaying the loan.

loans.use: Purchase two calves and one milking cow

loans.name: Sevindik

texts.en:
Sevindik S. is 50 years old. He is married and has three sons. From a young age, Sevindik learned to operate a small business from his parents. Through a lot of sacrifice, he has become one of the leading producers of agriculture for the area in which he lives. He continued working in the same business after he was married. With the income from the business, he was able to raise cattle successfully. In addition to his livestock business, Sevindik also teaches children at school.

Sevindik hopes to continue growing and improving his livestock business so he can offer a better future to his children. He would like to see them develop into professional, ethical, and hard-working adults. He is requesting a loan of 1200 USD to buy livestock, since raising and selling animals generates an excellent profit.

loans.use: Purchase one milking cow and two calves

loans.name: Veysal

texts.en:
Veysal M. is a hard-working person who tries to provide the best for his 3 beloved children. He decided to stay in his homeland so that he could develop it. He carries out his everyday chores with a lot of love and affection as he cultivates the land and feeds his animals.

Over the past 6 years, Veysal has gained experience in the purchase and sale of sheep, and his business has brought stability to his family. He would now like to purchase more sheep so he can better support his large family. He is requesting a loan of 1200 USD for a term of 15 months. Veysal thanks you very much.

loans.use: Purchase 15 sheep and fodder

loans.name: Elshad

texts.en:
Elshad H. is a 32-year-old entrepreneur who sells different kinds of foodstuffs and detergents in his store. His store is very famous in his community, so he has a good clientele. He also works as a policeman in the police department of the city where he lives, but his salary is not enough to cover the basic needs of his family. When he is at work, his wife replaces him in the store.

Today Elshad is requesting a loan of 1200 USD for the term of 15 months to increase his store's stock. He is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices, and push every once in a while to achieve his goal of becoming a successful entrepreneur. Elshad’s main goal is to educate his beloved children so that someday they’ll become successful entrepreneurs. His perseverance and clear vision will be key factors in the success of his small business.

loans.use: Purchase more food inventory

loans.name: Nukra

texts.en: Nukra A. is 38 years old. She is a widow and has four children. Nukra sells food items such as tea, sunflower oil, infants formula, mayonnaise, butter and sweets. She rents a place for selling in one of the local markets. Nukra has been running her own small business for four years. Her elder son helps Nukra with the business. The income she derives allows her to provide for family expenses. Considering that she is the only breadwinner in her family, Nukra works very hard to give her dearest children a good education and make them happy. Today she requests 3000 Somoni ($ 900) for the term of 12 months. Nukra thanks everyone for the support and promises to pay the loan in time. Be an important part of the growth of Nukra’s business.

loans.use: Purchasing of food items to increase her range of goods

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Married with 5 children between the ages of 8-23, 38 years old Annet M.  runs a clothing business on a retail basis. Her shop is located along Iganga road, in Jinja town and has been in existence for 4 years. She has one lady employee who helps her with the daily transactions of the business. 

This loan will enable Annet to buy more gomeses (Ugandan traditional wear), handbags, and shoes, among other fine fabrics, for her shop. This is timely, because the Christmas season is at hand, and clothing sales are shooting up. From the profits, she saves a portion that will help her attain her dream of running a wholesale clothes shop within the same locality.

loans.use: Buy more gomeses (Ugandan traditional wear), handbags, and shoes, among other fine fabrics, for her shop.

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy A. is 40 years old and runs a retail clothing business. She also sells some mobile phones from her shop which is located along the main street in Jinja town. Her business has been in existence for a period of 5 years. She is requesting this loan to purchase additional supplies of dresses, ladies suits, gents shirts and trousers including some mobile phones in preparation for the anticipated increase in demand of these products during the upcoming festive season.

The income from this business enables her to care for her 4 children, pay her lady shop assistant, settle the shop rent and utility bills. Her great dream is to accumulate enough capital  to enable her to operate a clothes wholesale business instead of the present retail shop.

loans.use: Purchase more dresses, ladies suits, gents shirts and trousers including some mobile phones.

loans.name: Nizami

texts.en:
Nizami V. is a hard-working man who strives every day to provide for his wife and five children. He manages a general store where he sells many staples such as soap, food, and kitchen utensils. Although he started this business only three years ago with less than $300, Nizami has attracted a strong base of customers who are impressed by his efforts to travel to neighboring cities to purchase especially valuable items.

Nizami is requesting a loan of 1200 USD in order to purchase additional foodstuffs and increase his store's inventory.

loans.use: purchase more kitchen utensils

loans.name: Mursal

texts.en:
Mursal H. is very young and proactive entrepreneur who is 27 years old. He built a grocery store two years ago; he sells a wide variety of foodstuffs, including cookies, candies, soft drinks, juices, and tea. He married just recently, and his wife actively helps him in his store. Musal also works as a policeman in the police department of Bilasuver, the city where he is living now.

Mursal has applied for a loan of 1200 USD to purchase more food to add to his store's inventory. By expanding his business, Mursal will attract more clients and earn more income.

loans.use: Purchase more food to expand his store's inventory

loans.name: Khaitgul

texts.en: Khaitgul E. is married and the mother of five children. Her husband works primarily as a specialty fisherman. Because of very difficult conditions at home, she has been compelled to work to help cover household expenses. That is why she started selling basic food items. Given the flood of customer demand, she tried turning to loan sharks for help, but they made her situation worse with their exorbitant interest rates. So she is requesting a loan of 1000 Somoni ($300) as capital to stock and transport food items, in order to improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To increase her range of goods

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Vivant dans la sous préfecture de Selingué (Village de sélékégni) située au situé au bord du fleuve sankarani abritant le barrage hydro électrique de selingué (lieu touristique et propice à la riziculture et à la pêche), les membres du groupe benkadi sont des femmes mariées vivant dans des foyers polygames avec en moyenne cinq (5) enfants. Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinnage.
Spécialisées dans la vente de poissons (fraiches ou fumées), elles s’approvisionnent sur place tous les jours auprès des pêcheurs et vendent sur place. Souvent une partie est fumée et vendue à Bamako. Avec cette recette elles achetent des articles divers (Pâgnes; chaussures et bijoux) à Bamako qui sont vendus à la population de Selingué.
Avec ce prêt elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 55.000 FCFA par membre pour subvénir aux bésoins de leur famille. Elles désirent à la longue acquérir un congelateur pour mieux concerver le poisson
texts.en:
The members of the Benkadi group live in the sous-prefecture of Selingué (village of Sélékégni) which is situated on the bank of the Sankarani river that is home to the hydro-electric dam of Selingué (a tourist site which lends itself to growing rice and to fishing). They are married women living in polygamous households with an average of 5 children each. They know each other because they come from the same neighborhood.

Specialized in selling fish (fresh or smoked), they do their buying daily right where they live from the fishermen, and they also sell the fish there. Often, a part of the catch is smoked and sent to Bamako (the capital of Mali). With that revenue, they buy various articles ("pagnes"--lengths of brightly colored African print cloth, shoes and costume jewelry) in Bamako for re-sale to the population of Selingué.

With this loan, they expect to make an average monthly profit of 55,000 F CFA per member to pay family expenses. In the long run, they hope to acquire a freezer so that they can keep their fish fresh more easily.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy fish and rice

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
48 year old Everlyn S. is a hardworking and sociable mother of 5 children. She is married and a business woman by profession. She sells ladies and childrens wear in the Buwenge market zone on a retail basis. She has been operating this business for 25 years. She keeps her business running by keeping good records of her daily sales to determine the sales and profits realized. 

Everlyn will use this loan to purchase ladies suits, baby shawls, childrens dresses, and scarves, among other items, to meet  the needs of her customers. She hopes to use the profits from the business to establish a wholesale garments shop specifically for childrens wear within the Buwenge area. With a wholesale business in operation, she hopes to send her children to the best schools in the country.

loans.use: Purchase additional supplies of ladies suits, baby shawls, children’s dresses, scarves and others items.

loans.name: Djumagul

texts.en: Djumagul S. has an established business selling kids' clothing in her store. She started her business about nine years ago. She has an entrepreneurial mind, and she has worked hard to develop her business. Buying clothing inventory from Istaravshan, where she can get better prices, is one way in which she is able to gain a competitive business advantage. Moreover, she is planning on bringing goods in from China. Djumagul is married, and she has four children. One of her goals for the future is to provide all of her children with houses. Djumagul is requesting a loan of 3500 Somoni in order to purchase winter clothing. With additional clothing, she will be able to increase her sales and will continue to provide a better life for herself and her family.

loans.use: Purchasing winter clothing to sell

loans.name: Ausi

texts.en:
Ausi W. is 40 years old, married with four children attending school. He operates a grocery shop, along the Kaliro road in Lganga to supplement his income from farming.  The business earns an average profit of 150,000 UGX per month, from which he pays a yearly rent of 1,200,000 UGX. During the five years that he has run this business, W. has earned the loyalty of his customers by ensuring that he provides great customer care. He will use the loan to purchase additional supplies of sugar, flour, salt, rice, and maize among other products, for his business.

Ensuring his children achieve a university education is one his desires. Ausi also has hopes of running a supermarket in the future. He would then be in position to construct rental houses and a build a residence for his family.

loans.use: Purchase additional supplies of sugar, flour, salt, rice, maize and other products for his business.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty K. is a 40 years old mother of three children. Her children are between the ages of 8-18. Two are in high school while the youngest is in primary school. Betty is a hardworking business woman who has been selling poultry feeds in Jinja town for a period of 15 years. She has created employment opportunities for three people. Because of increased customer demands, she is requesting this loan to replenish her supplies of maize brand flour and fish for her factory. 

Betty’s dream is to acquire a larger machine that will enable her produce feeds in greater quantities. With this in place, she will be assured of seeing her children through school successfully and providing them with a modern new residence.

loans.use: To purchase additional supplies of maize brand flour and fish for her factory.
