Elles  sollicitent ce prêt de 100 000 FCFA membre, pour acheter,  600  kilogrammes de grains de néré (fruit d’un arbre oléagineux de la région sahélienne) et de bois de chauffe pour la cuisson des noix. 
Le cycle de production et de vente effective dure en moyenne trois (3) semaines. Le Sounbala fini est acheminé sur Bamako souvent sur le Sénégal pour être vendu en espèce souvent à crédit. 
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen par cycle de 33.000  FCFA qui sera utilisé pour essentiellement renforcer le fonds de commerce.
texts.en:
The members of the group SIGUIDJA are married women who live in polygamous households and who average 39 years of age and five children. The know one another by ties of friendship and family, and they all reside in the sub-prefecture of Ouéléssébougou, located 80 km from the Bamako, the capital of Mali (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). This group is specialized in making and selling "sounbala", a highly-appreciated food product that is sought after for making sauces in West Africa.

They learned how to make sounbala at an early age from their mothers. In other words, it's about an ancient body of knowledge passed down from generation to generation. Basically, the néré seeds, once they are properly cleaned, are boiled, pounded, and then kneaded in order to make a dark, edible dough called 'sounbala', which is formed into several different shape.

The group members are on their fourth loan with the Soro Yiriwaso loan program. All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid. The women are requesting a loan of 100,000 francs CFA each to buy 600 kg of néré seeds (the fruit of an oil-producing tree in the Sahel region) and firewood for cooking the seeds.

The production cycle and actual sales occur over the course of three weeks. The finished sounbala is taken to Bamako and often to Senegal to be sold in cash and often on credit. The group members hope to realize an average per-cycle profit of 33,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to boost their working capital.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy néré seeds

loans.name: Pov

texts.en: Mrs. Pov C. is a 48-year-old who lives in Trapaing Thnaut village in Takeo Province. She is a pig breeder. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to request a loan to buy more pigs and pig food for her breeding business. She hopes to increase income and improve her living conditions with this loan. Her husband, Mr. Kak Pan, is a construction worker. Mrs. Pov C. has three children, one of whom stays at home to do housework while the others are enrolled in the local school. Her husband is presented with her in the picture.

loans.use: To buy more pigs and pig food for her breeding business.

loans.name: Kate

texts.en:
Kate O. is 40 years old and is married with six children. All of her children are in school. Kate sells provisions and drinks. She also sells firewood. Kate makes the most profit from the sale of provisions and drinks.

Kate needs a loan in the amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell. She would like to express her gratitude to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Joel

texts.en:
Joel is married to Marnelie, who chose to become a housewife to take good care of their only child, Princess Joan Mae. Still young at the age of 27, he is very aggressive in continuously improving his cell phone shop. By doing so, he knows that more customers will come in, thus providing more income and savings for his family. His cell phone shop has been their sole source of income since they got married. His family is now living in Barangay Arcon, Tumauini, Isabela, Philippines.

Because of his goal to make his business successful, Joel has decided to borrow money to use as his additional capital. He knows that success is only possible if he expands his business. Also, he plans to start a new venture: a hog-raising business that he has engaged in before. He wants to borrow at least Php7, 000 to assist him in fulfilling his dreams.

“The bottom line in a business' success is patience, hard work, and, most of all, trust in God,” Joel says.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Channa

texts.en: Mr. Channa C. is a villager in Kdey Thnaut village in Takeo Province. He is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. His wife, Mrs. Son Vanna, is a housewife and she now wants to start a duck breeding business. Thus, Mr. Channa C. decided to ask for a loan to purchase some ducklings and duck food for breeding. He hopes to increase his income and improve his living conditions with this loan. He is 38 years old and the father of two children who are attending the local school. His wife is presented on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To purchase some ducklings and duck food for breeding.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Vivant dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village Bougoula Hameau, situé à environ 3km de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali, les membres du goupe Benkadi (8 femmes: 7 mariées et 1 célibataire) avec en moyenne 3 enfants et une moyenne d’âge de 34 ans). Ce groupe est une émmanation de l’association Badeya  unie par des liens  de parentés (des soeurs et cousines) et qui a pour activités génératrices de revenus l’achat et  la vente d’huile d’arachide,  de riz, de savons, de noix de Néré, des  produits de beauté, du «Soumbala » et des  condiments alimentaires. Le “Soumbala” est fait à base des noix de Néré après cuisson. 
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de sa clièntele qui ne cesse d’augmenter, ce groupe décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son 4ème cycle du prêt solidaire (prêt du groupe). Tous ses prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Elles (les femmes du groupe) sollicitent ce prêt pour pouvoir acheter, 2 bariques d’huile d’arachide, 13 sacs de riz, 5 sacs de noix de Néré et une grande quantité de condiments (2 sacs d’oignon, 2 sacs d’aubergine, 1 sacs de gombo, 5 paquets d’arome , 5 boîtes de concentré tomate).
 Les villes de Bobo Dioulasso et de Bamako (respectivent au Burkina Faso et au Mali) sont les principales sources d’approvisionnement possibles des femmes de ce groupe. Les marchandises sont achiminées à Sikasso les jours de foire pour être vendues au comptant, à la fois en gros et détail à une clientèle composée très généralement des femmes et surtout des foraines. 
Les marchandises sont vendues au comptant et à crédits soit au marché local, soit à la maison à une clientèle locale feminine.
Elles (les femmes du groupe) envisagent réaliser chacune avec ce 4ème prêt un bénéfice moyen de 50.000 FCFA par mois qui sera utiliser pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir  aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités respectives.
texts.en:
Living in traditional extended families in the village of Bougoula Hameau, located about 3 km from the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali), the members of the group Benkadi (8 women: 7 married and 1 unmarried) average 3 children and 34 years of age. This group came out of the association Badeya and is united by ties of kinship (sisters and cousins). The group members work to earn an income by trading in peanut oil, rice, soap, néré seeds, beauty products, condiments, and "soumbala", which is made from cooked néré seeds.

To satisfy their ever-increasing customer base, they decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution, with which they are on their fourth solidarity loan cycle (group loan). All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid.

The women of the group are requesting this loan to buy: 2 barrels of peanut oil, 13 sacks of rice, 5 sacks of néré seeds, and a sizable quantity of condiments (2 sacks of onions, 2 of eggplant, 1 of okra, 5 packets of flavorings, and 5 cans of tomato paste). The cities of Bobo Dioulasso and Bamako (respectively in Burkina Faso and Mali) are the main sources of supplies possible for the women.

The goods are taken to Sikasso on market days to be sold in cash at wholesale and retail levels, both. Their customers are generally composed of women and especially market vendors. Sales are made either at the local marketplace or out of homes, cash or credit accepted.

Using this fourth loan, the women each envision realizing an average profit of 50,000 francs CFA that will be used to pay the loan interest, to provide for the family, and to invest the rest into their respective businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy conditments, peanut oil, rice, soap, néré seeds, beauty products

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Danaya ( 5 femmes toutes mariées) avec en moyenne 4 enfants et une moyenne d’âge de 36 ans  vivent dans des foyers traditionnels  au village Bougoula Hameau situé à environ 3km de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
 Ce groupement composé des amies et voisines a pour activités génératrices de revenus l’achat et la vente de savon,  du bois de chauffe,de  céréales,de noix de Néré et de « Soumbala » ( fabriqué à base de noix de Néré).
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de sa clièntele qui ne cesse d’augmenter, ce groupe a decidé d’integrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son 3ème cycle du prêt solidaire (prêt du groupe). Tous ses prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés
Elles (les femmes du groupe) sollicitent ce prêt pour pouvoir acheter 10 sacs de riz et 10 sacs de maïs.
Les villes de Niono et de Sikasso (respectivement en 4ème et 3ème régions) sont les principales sources d’approvisionnement possibles des femmes de ce groupe. Les marchandises sont achiminées à Sikasso les jours de foire et aussi Bougoula Hameau pour être vendues au comptant, à la fois en gros et détail à une clientèle composée très généralement des femmes et surtout des foraines. Les ventes sont effectuées soit au marché local, soit à domicile au comptant et à crédit à une clienèle composée des femmes du village.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune avec ce 3ème prêt un bénéfice moyen de 30.000 FCFA par mois qui sera utiliser pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir  aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités respectives.
texts.en:
The members of the Danaya group, 5 women all married, are on average 36 years old with 4 children on average. They live in traditional households in the village Bougoula Hameau located about 3 km from the town of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali). The income generating activity of this group, made of friends and neighbors, is the purchase and sale of soap, firewood, cereals, néré tree nuts and “Soumbala” (an edible paste made of néré nuts).

In order to satisfy the ever-increasing demand of their customers, this group has decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso with whom they have already completed 3 solidarity loan cycles (group loans). All their previous loans were fully reimbursed.

They (the women from the group) are requesting this loan to be able to purchase 10 bags of rice and 10 bags of corn. The towns of Niono and Sikasso (respectively 4th and 3rd regions) are the principal source of supply available for the women of this group. The goods are transported to Sikasso on market days and also to Bougoula Hameau to be sold for cash both wholesale and retail to a clientele composed usually of women and mostly fairground women. The sales take place either at the local market or door to door, for cash or credit to a clientele made up of women from the village. With this 3rd loan, each of them plans to make an average profit of 30, 000 FCFA per month that will be used to repay the loan, provide for the family’s needs and invest the rest in their respective activities.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of soap, friewood, cereals and néré nuts.

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia Igbinomwahia is 51 years old and is married with six children. Felicia owns a store where she sells provisions, drinks, and foodstuffs. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria.

Felicia needs a loan in the amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more provisions, drinks, and foodstuffs to sell. Felicia is happy because she will make additional profits during this festive season. She would like to thank everyone that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions, drinks, and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To add to her savings to purchase tiles to make floor tiles for her house.

loans.name: Happiness

texts.en:
Happiness I. O. is 54 years old and is married with seven children. Happiness purchases drinks from distributors in Benin City to sell to her customers. She is happy because the demand for her drinks will increase during this festive season.

Happiness needs a loan in the amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more drinks to sell. She would like to thank all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Jiguisèmè Group

texts.fr:
Le groupement Jiguisèmè (composé de 6 femmes 5 mariées et 1célibataire avec en moyenne 3 enfants et une moyenne d’âge de 19 ans) est crée à travers une association de leur village (Association Badeya de Bougoula Hameau) situé à environ 3km de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). Ce groupement composé des soeurs et cousines a pour activités génératrices de revenus l’achat et la vente des condiments, légumes, riz et tissus.
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de sa clièntele qui ne cesse d’augmenter, ce groupe decida d’integrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son 4ème cycle du prêt solidaire (prêt du groupe). Tous ses prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Les femmes du groupe sollicitent ce prêt pour pouvoir acheter; 40 sacs de riz et un importants stock de condiments (2 sacs d’oignon, 2 sacs d’aubergine, 1 sacs de gombo, 5 paquets de cubes maggie, 5 boîtes de concentré tomate, etc.) La ville Sikasso et ses environs sont les principales sources d’approvisionnement des femmes de ce groupe. Les marchandises sont achiminées à Bougoula Hameau les jours de foire pour être vendues au comptant, à la fois en gros et détail à une clientèle composée très généralement des femmes et surtout des foraines. Les marchandises sont vendues au comptant et à crédit soit au marché local, soit à la maison à une clientèle locale feminine.
Elles  envisagent réaliser chacune  un bénéfice moyen de 60.000 FCFA par mois qui sera utiliser pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir  aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités respectives.
texts.en:
The group Jiguisèmè (composed of six women, of whom five are married and one is unmarried and who average 19 years of age and three children) was created through an association in their village (Association Badeya de Bougoula Hameau) located about 3 km from the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). This group of sisters and cousins works to earn an income by trading in condiments, vegetables, rice, and cloth.

To satisfy their ever-increasing customer base, the group members decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution, with which they are on their fourth solidarity loan cycle (group loan). All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid.

These women are requesting this loan to buy 40 sacks of rice and a sizable stock of condiments (2 sacks of onions, 2 of eggplant, 1 of okra, 5 packets of Maggie bouillon cubes, 5 cans of tomato paste, etc.). Sikasso and the surrounding areas are the main source of supplies for them. The goods are taken to Bougoula Hameau on market days to be sold in cash and at the wholesale and retail levels, both. Their customers are generally composed of women and especially market vendors. Sales are made either at the local market or out of homes, cash or credit accepted.

They each envision realizing an average profit of 60,000 francs CFA per month that will be used to pay the loan interest, to support the family, and to invest the rest into their respective businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments, vegetables, rice, and cloth

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en:
Dorcas A. is 40 years old and is married with six children. Dorcas sells foodstuffs like okra, pepper, onions, palm and vegetable oil, etc. The demand for her foodstuffs is high.

She needs a loan in the amount of 30,000 NGN to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She would like to thank everyone that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Kotognogontala Group

texts.fr:
Kotognogontala est un regroupement composé de 6 femmes toutes mariées ayant en moyenne 4 enfants et  37 ans qui vit dans des familles traditionnelles élargies au village Bougoula Hameau de la préfecture de Sikasso(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
 Unies par des relations de voisinage et d’alliance ces femmes mènent des activités génératrices de revenus  diverses et variées. En plus de leur activité principale qui est l’achat et la vente des condiments alimentaires, elles vont la vente, de poissons fumés, de tasses,  de baignoires , de vêtements  pour enfants etc.
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de sa clièntele qui ne cesse d’augmenter, ce groupe décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son 4ème  prêt solidaire (prêt du groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Ce quatrième leur permettra d’acheter, 13 caisses de tomate, 10 sacs de noix de Néré, 2 sacs d’oignon, 2 sacs d’aubergine, 1 sac de gombo, 5 paquets de cubes maggie, 5 boîtes de concentré tomate, etc.
Généralement elles achètent leurs marchandises au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso et les ventes sont effectuées soit au marché local, soit à domicile au comptant et à crédit à une clienèle composée des femmes du village.Elles envisagent réaliser chacune avec ce 4ème prêt un bénéfice moyen de 15.000 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé appuiyer les activités, payer les intérêts du prêt et à participer aux dépenses de leurs familles respectives.
texts.en:
Kotognogontala is a group composed of six women, all married, averaging four children and 37 years of age. They live in traditional extended families in the village of Bougoula Hameau, Sikasso Prefecture (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). United by ties of community and alliances, these women do various and varied work to earn an income. In addition to their main work, which is commerce in condiments, they sell smoked fish, cups, tubs, clothing for children, etc.

To satisfy their every-increasing customer base, the group members decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution, with which they are on their fourth solidarity loan (group loan). All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid. This four loan will enable them to buy: 13 boxes of tomatoes, 10 sacks of néré seeds, 2 sacks of onions, 2 of eggplant, 1 of okra, 5 packets of Maggie bouillon cubes, 5 cans of tomato paste, etc.

Generally, they buy their merchandise at the grand marketplace of the city of Sikasso. Sales are made either at the local marketplace or out of homes, cash or credit accepted, to customers composed of village women.

Using this fourth loan, they each envision realizing an average profit of 15,000 francs CFA per month that will be used to support the businesses, to pay the loan interest, and to help cover the expenses of their respective families.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments, smoked fish, cups, tubs, rice, and children's clothing

loans.name: Maureen

texts.en:
Maureen U. is 40 years old and is married with two children. Maureen sells foodstuffs, drinks, and provisions. Her store is located in a busy area. Maureen hopes to make more sales during this festive season.

Maureen needs a loan in the amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more foodstuffs, drinks, and provisions to sell. She would like to thank everyone that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs, drinks, and provisions to sell

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupement Sabougnouma ( 7 femmes toutes mariées) avec en moyenne 5 enfants et une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans vivent dans des foyers polygames au village Bougoula Hameau situé à environ 3km de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative de la république du Mali). Très dynamiques ces femmes composées des cousines et voisines font de l’achat  vente de condiments,de céréales et de tissus. En plus elles font la transformation des noix de néré en “soumbala” un produit alimentaire très prisé dans la préparation des sauces et qui a des vertues appréciées.
Ce groupe collabore avec le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenat deux ans.Il est à son 3ème  prêt solidaire (prêt du groupe) et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Ce troisième prêt qu’elles sollicitent leur permettra d’acheter, 20 sacs de noix de Néré, 2 sacs d’oignon, 2 sacs d’aubergine, 1 sac de gombo, 5 paquets de maggie, 5 boîtes de concentré tomate, etc. Généralement les marchandises sont achetées au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso auprès des producteurs et commerçants grossistes. Les ventes sont effectuées soit au marché local, soit  à domicile au comptant et à crédit à une clienèle composée des femmes du village.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune avec ce 3ème prêt un bénéfice moyen de 13.000 FCFA par mois qui sera utiliser pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir  aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités respectives.
texts.en:
The members of the group Sabougnouma (composed of seven married women) average five children and 38 years of age. They live in polygamous households in the village of Bougoula Hameau, located about 3 km from the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Cousins and neighbors, they are very energetic women who do commerce in condiments, grain, and cloth. In addition, they process néré seeds into “soumbala”, a highly-prized food product with virtues appreciated for making sauces.

This group has been collabroating with the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso for two years now. It is on its third solidarity loan (group loan). All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid. The current loan the group members are requesting will enable them to buy: 20 sacks of néré seeds, 2 sacks of onions, 2 of eggplant, 1 of okra, 5 packets of Maggie bouillon cubes, 5 cans of tomato paste, etc. The merchandise is generally purchases at the grand marketplace in Sikasso from producers and wholesale merchants. Sales are made either at the local marketplace or out of homes, cash or credit accepted, to customers composed village women.

Using this third loan, they each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 13,000 francs CFA that will be used to pay the loan interest, to provide for the family, and to invest the rest into their respective businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments, grain, and cloth

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen O. O. is 42 years old and she is married with three children. Helen lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells sarongs and firewood. Helen needs the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more sarongs and firewood to sell.  She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and firewood to sell

loans.name: Svitlana

texts.en:
Svitlana is divorced with a teenage son. It has been difficult for her to raise her son all by herself and provide for all the needs of a growing guy. She knew she had to find ways to generate enough income for their needsm  so she decided to launch her cafeteria business 6 years ago. She establish a policy of offering nutritious, high quality, and affordable meals to all workers in the industrial area where she runs her business. 

Svitlana is hoping to purchase groceries for the winter season. Assorted merchandise will give her a chance to offer additional affordable dishes on the menu and please her customers’ tastes. 

Svitlana is requesting a loan of 5000 Grivna and is hoping to repay it in 6 months. One of her long-term plans is to remodel her private apartment and purchase the facility she currently rents for her cafeteria.

loans.use: To purchase groceries for cooking

loans.name: Sinignèsigui Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Sinignèsigui ( 7 femmes,  6 mariées et 1 célibataire) vivent dans des familles polygames avec en moyenne 5 enfants et  42 ans dans le  village de Bougoula Hameau situé à environ 3 km de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
 Elles exercent le petit commerce d’articles divers notamment les condiments alimentaires, le bois de chauffe, les chaussures et les céréales. 
Se faisant mutuellement confiance et dans le soucis de mieux satisfaire leur clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elles décidèrent d’intégrer le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec lequel le groupe est à son 2 ème  du prêt solidaire (prêt du groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Avec ce deuxième prêt, elles comptent acheter 10 sacs de tomate, 10 sacs de piment, 10 sacs d’oignon, 10 sacs d’aubergine, 10 paquets de maggie, 10 boîtes de concentré tomate, etc. Les marchandises sont achetées au grand marché de Sikasso et vendues vendues au comptant et à crédit au marché du quartier et à la maison à une clientèle locale feminine. 
Elles envisagent augmenter subtentiellement leur profit en réalisant chacune un bénéfice moyen de 10.000 FCFA par mois qui sera utiliser pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir  aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités respectives.
texts.en:
The members of the Sinignèsigui group ( 7 women: 6 married and 1 single) live in polygamous families with, on average, 5 children and an average age of 42, in the village of Bougoula Hameau, situated 3 km from the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

They retail various small items, notably condiments, firewood, shoes, and cereals. Trusting each other and hoping to better satisfy their ever-growing clientele, they decided to join the credit program of Soro Yiriwaso, with whom they are on their second group loan (solidarity loan). The previous loan was correctly reimbursed.

With this second loan, they intend to buy 10 sacks of tomatoes, 10 sacks of hot peppers, 10 sacks of onions, 10 sacks of eggplant, 10 packets of Maggi, 10 boxes of tomato concentrate, etc. The merchandise is bought in the big open-air market of Sikasso and sold, for cash or credit, in the neighborhood market and out of their homes, to a local clientele consisting of women.

They expect to substantially increase their profit, each of them making an average profit of 10,000 F CFA per month which will be used to make repayments on the loan and cover family expenses, with the remainder invested back into their respective businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of condiments, rice, shoes, and firewood

loans.name: Zohir

texts.en:
Selling office supplies on the street has become the only source of income for A. Zohir, a humble, 33-year-old young man who's been doing this for 7 years. 

This young man has many projects for his future. The main project is to open his own store where he would be able to sell office supplies and books. He's good at what he does; this is why he's been able to support his family, especially his dearest five children, with education. 

His wish is to add more books and, therefore, to have more to offer to his clients. He will pay back this loan and, with the money, he will be able to pay for his children’s education. 

This young man waits for your help. Let's make his dream come true.

loans.use: Office supplies for students

loans.name: Olga

texts.en:
Olga owns a small cafeteria in an industrial district of Uzhgorod, Western Ukraine. She offers quality services and delicious meals to all workers of this factory zone (4 factories in the district). Olga has been in the trade for 6 years. Her perseverance, confidence, experience and consistency in work have guaranteed the growth of her business. She is constantly increasing the assortment of dishes she serves in her cafeteria, which helps her increase her income.

Olga is presently renting the facility which serves as her cafeteria. She is hoping to generate enough income and eventually to purchase these premises, which would give her more flexibility and income as a result. Olga is very focused. She is a typical high-achiever and knows how to set goals and achieve them. 

This time, she is requesting a loan of 5000 Grivnas to purchase additional grocery items to diversify her cafeteria menu. She is hoping to repay the current loan in 6 months.

loans.use: To purchase additional grocery items

loans.name: Nozira

texts.en: Nozira is 32 years old and the mother of 5 children.  She is married, and her husband has no fixed job.  The family has had difficult moments because her husband hasn't earned enough, and in order to obtain the necessary resources to support the children and pay their school fees, Nozira decided to start her own business selling clothes.  She started her business 10 years ago.  She started her business with a small investment in merchandise.  However, due to high competition, she has been acquiring greater amounts of clothing, which has helped increase her earnings, albeit very slowly.  Fortunately, sales and orders from clients have increased.  In order to meet the demand for her products, Nozira needs a loan in the amount of 3500 Somoni, which she promises to return over a period of 6 months.  You can improve the conditions of this family's lifestyle.  They are grateful for your generosity and support.

loans.use: To purchase winter clothing in order to increase her range of goods for selling.

loans.name: Mukaramkhon

texts.en: Mukaramkhon M. is 50 years old.  She is married with 4 children.  Mukaramkhon started her business in 1994 after being retrenched from the company she was working for.  With her retrenchment money, Mukaramkhon immediately rented a shop and opened a cosmetic shop.  The business has been doing very well up to now and Mukaramkhon has been able to generate a good income from it.  She now wants to increase the stock in her shop, which will enable her customers to have a better variety of cosmetics to choose from, and they will be able to get any products they require at her shop.  Mukaramkhon is therefore requesting a loan of 4000 Somoni ($1200 USD) which she will use to purchase much-needed products like shampoo, soap and perfumes for her shop.  The repayment period for her loan will be 6 months.  She expresses her gratitude for everyone supporting her.

loans.use: To purchase perfumes and cosmetics in order to increase the range of goods for selling.

loans.name: Natalya

texts.en:
Natalya sells food items, e.g. candy and sweets, in the grocery section of her local marketplace. She has been in this trade for two years. One of the significant factors that motivated her to start her own business was a need to provide for her family. Currently, Natalya has about 20,000 Grivnas in inventory. Her turnover capital amounts to 8,000 Grivnas and net profit is about 3,384 Grivnas a month.

Natalya’s business has grown to be self-sustainable. It has passed different formation stages, as well as survival, growth and stable consistency in sales. Today she is seeking a loan for 5,000 Grivnas to re-stock her merchandise for the winter season. Natalya is hoping to generate additional income with new grocery products and increased sales.

loans.use: To re-stock her merchandise for the winter season

loans.name: Kakakuona Group

texts.en:
Musa B. is a 32-year-old married man with two children (ages 4 and 2). He has a general shop where he sells different kinds of products. He started this business in 2005, and he works daily from 6 am until 10 pm. By doing so, he is able to earn a monthly profit of approximately $195.

Musa is seeking for a loan through Tujijenge Tanzania to increase his working capital so that he can buy more goods and inventory for his general store. Notably, Musa would share the loan proceeds with his loan group, Kakakuona, which totals 15 members. In this group, members guarantee each others' loans (i.e., if one member does not promptly repay his or her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears), and they provide support for one another to repay their respective loans. In the picture, Musa is standing third from the right in the back row.

loans.use: To increase his general store's inventory

loans.name: Kazimoto Group

texts.en:
Mwanaid S. is a 35-year-old divorced woman with 2 children (ages 18 and 10). She has a business where she sells charcoal and firewood, which she started 5 years ago. She works on a daily basis from 7 am to 6 pm daily, and by doing so she is able to earn a monthly profit of approximately $160.

Mwanaid has already received one previous loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to expand and improve her business, and she proudly states that she promptly repaid that loan. Now, she is seeking a second loan to increase her inventory by buying more charcoal and firewood. Notably, Mwanaid would share the loan proceeds with her loan group, Kazimoto, which totals 24 members. In this group, members guarantee each others' loans (i.e., if one member does not promptly repay his or her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears), and they provide support for one another to repay their respective loans. In the picture, Mwanaid is squatting third from the left.

loans.use: To further expand her business by purchasing additional firewood and charcoal.

loans.name: Tujumuike Group

texts.en:
Sabina T. is a 34-year-old single woman. She has 3 children (ages 11, 8, and 4), but she also cares for another dependent. She has not one but two businesses: she sells milk (she owns 3 cows), and she has a “Mama Lishe” (a small outdoor café where she sells drinks and hot snacks). She started these businesses 8 years ago, and she works on a daily basis from 7 am until 8 pm. By doing so, she is able to earn approximately $224 per month from her milk-selling business and $120 per month from her Mama Lishe.

Sabina has already received one prior loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to expand and improve her businesses, and she promptly repaid that particular loan. Now, she is applying for another loan in order to buy items such as oil and rice for her café, as well as cow feed for her three cows. Notably, Sabina will share the loan proceeds with her loan group, Tujumuike, which totals 15 members. In this group, members guarantee each others' loans (i.e., if one member does not promptly repay his or her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears), and they provide support for one another to repay their respective loans. In the picture, Sabina is standing on the left.

loans.use: To further expand her businesses by purchasing oil and rice (for her café) and cow feed (for her milk-selling business).

loans.name: Rubina Zakir Ali Group

texts.en:
Rubina baji is a 57-year-old lady and resides in a city named Vehari, Pakistan. She owes a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the past 5 years. Her husband's name is Z. A., and he is a milkman and sells milk in milk shops as well as in the community. He has been in this profession for the past 25 years. Rubina baji helps her husband in getting milk from the buffalo. They both get up early in the morning and get 12 kg milk and fill the milk jars. Presently they have one buffalo and they want to buy another buffalo to expand their milk selling business. 

She is a group leader of a few women in her locality. These women are very responsible and cooperative. Nazia Noreen baji wants a loan to buy animals (goats) for her butcher shop. Tasleem baji wants a loan to buy animals (goats and sheep) for her animal selling business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy another buffalo for milk selling

loans.name: Sisi Kwa Sisi Group

texts.en:
Grace J. C. is a 37-year-old single woman with three children (a 14-year-old and twin 10-year-olds). She has a clothing shop where she sells ladies' clothes and materials at Kinondoni A. She started this business three years ago, and she works on a daily basis from 8:30 am until 7 pm. By doing so, she is able to earn a monthly profit of approximately $184.

This is the first loan Grace has sought via Tujijenge Tanzania. With the loan proceeds, she hopes to buy more inventory for her shop, such as ladies' suits and clothes for the Christmas sales season. Notably, Grace will share the loan proceeds with her loan group, Sisi kwa sisi, which totals 15 members. In this group, members guarantee each others' loans (i.e., if one member does not promptly repay his or her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears), and they provide support for one another to repay their respective loans. In the picture, Grace is standing all the way on the right in the back row.

loans.use: To capitalize on the prime shopping season by purchasing additional inventory (e.g., women's clothing and Christmas items)

loans.name: Khursheed Nazir Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Khursheed baji is a 33-year-old lady and resides in a city named Vehari, Pakistan. She has been living in this city for the past 16 years. She is the mother of two children: one son and one daughter. Both of her kids are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Khursheed baji’s husband's name is N. A., and he has an animal selling business with experience of 15 years. He specifically sells goats and cows. Khursheed baji is a seamstress and has been stitching clothes for 15 years. She charges $2 per dress. She adopted this profession to support her husband to meet the household expenses. She successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more animals for her husband’s animal selling business. 

She is a group leader of a few women in her locality. Rubina baji wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Zahooran baji and Hajran baji each want a loan to buy animals (goats) for their animal selling business. baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy animals for animal selling business

loans.name: Kinyerezi Group

texts.en:
Obadia N. is a 30-year-old married man with a 4-year-old daughter. He owns and operates a shop where he sells beauty supplies and toiletries in an area called Kinyerezi. He started this business one year ago, and he works on a daily basis from 8 am until 6 pm. By doing so, he is able to earn a monthly profit of approximately $244.

This is the second loan that Obadia has sought via Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the first loan to increase the inventory at his shop, and he proudly states that he promptly repaid that particular loan. Now, he is seeking another loan in order to again expand his shop's inventory by purchasing items such as lotions, perfumes, and hair products. Notably, Obadia will share the loan proceeds with his loan group, Kinyerezi. In this group, members guarantee each others' loans (i.e., if one member does not promptly repay his or her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears), and they provide support for one another to repay their respective loans. In the picture, Obadia is standing on the right; also pictured are Rose I. (a shop and taxi owner) and Rose C. (a shop owner).

loans.use: To further expand his store's inventory by purchasing additional perfumes, lotions, and hair products.

loans.name: Tawofic

texts.en: Tawofic is 45 years old and married with four children. She lives in 0koko, Lagos state, Nigeria, where she makes a living selling cooked foods and drinks in her shop. She has been in this business for a long time. Tawofic is a LAPO client and needs the loan to buy more food to cook and more drinks to sell. She thanks everyone who makes this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more food and drinks

loans.name: Shahnaz Akhtar Waqar Masood Group

texts.en:
Shahnaz Akhtar baji is a 42-year-old lady and resides in a city named Vehari, Pakistan. She owes a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the past 17 years. She is the mother of one son who is 9 years old and reads in 3rd standard. Her husband's name is W. M., and he manufactures clothes and sells in cloth markets. He has been in this business for the past 17 years. Shahnaz baji makes embroidered dresses on order, which she takes from her neighbors. She charges $3 per embroidered dress. She is applying for a loan to buy another power loom machine to manufacture more clothes, because her husband is out of stock now and he needs to fulfill the orders of his customers. 

She is a group leader of a few more members in her locality. Asma baji wants a loan to buy furniture (chairs and tables) for her tuition center. Lubna Shahzadi baji wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Sobia Ashraf baji wants a loan to buy material (cloth, colored thread and sketches) for her decorative embroidery business. Zahooran baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy a power loom machine for manufacture clothes

loans.name: Ugomma

texts.en: Ugomma makes a living selling foodstuffs like bags of garri, a food made from cassava that's popular in West Africa. She has been in this business for a long time. Ugomma is 25 years old and married with one child. She hopes to be a major distributor of garri in future, and has applied for a loan to buy more of it to sell. She extends her thanks to everyone who helps make this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more food to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Parveen Nazir Masih Group

texts.en:
Parveen baji is a 34-year-old lady and resides in a city named Vehari, Pakistan. She has been living in this city for the past 25 years. She has one son who is 12 years old and reads in 4th standard. Parveen baji’s husband's name is N. M., and he works in a factory. Parveen baji is involved in a livestock business. She buys animals specifically (goats and sheep) from Lahore and sells in her native city of Vehari. She has been in this business for the past 12 years. She successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more animals (goat and sheep) to expand her animal selling business. 

She is a group leader of a few more members. Safia baji wants a loan to buy material (cloth, colored thread and sketches) for her decorative embroidery business. Farida baji wants a loan to buy animals (goats) for her animal selling business. Shamim baji and Suraiya baji each want a loan to buy seasonal fruits for their fruit selling businesses. Parveen baji wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy animals for animal selling business

loans.name: Mumtaz Akhtar Manzoor Hussain Group

texts.en:
Mumtaz Akhtar baji is a 27-year-old lady and resides in a city named Vehari, Pakistan. Her husband's name is M. H., and he works in a factory. Mumtaz baji owns a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the past 30 years. Mumtaz baji’s brother also lives with her, and he has a motor bike rental business. He gives motor bikes on rent and charges people $2 per hour. Mumtaz baji is a seamstress and stitches clothes by charging $2 per dress. Her husband earns less income, and she shares her income with him so that he able to manage household expenses easily and doesn’t feel any pressure. She is applying for a loan to repair the motor bikes of her brother. 

She is a group leader of a few more member in her locality. Saira baji wants a loan to buy wood to resell. Rukhsana baji wants a loan to buy another video game for her video game shop. Shumaila baji wants a loan to buy goats for her butcher shop. Samina baji wants a loan to buy wires for her electric shop. Rubina baji wants a loan to buy cigarettes to resell. Bashiran baji wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To repair motor bikes for rented motor bikes business

loans.name: Jafar

texts.en:
Jafar Y., a 29-year-old farmer with four years of experience breeding calves in Saatli, Azerbaijan, is married and has three children. An accountant by profession, he became unemployed in 2004 and so started his own business, assisted by his father, an experienced farmer. Now livestock breeding yields a stable monthly income, but more is needed to meet basic family needs and provide good living conditions for his three children.

To develop his business he needs to purchase more animals to sell, and therefore is requesting a loan of $1200 to purchase three calves and fodder. Let’s do our best to help this hardworking man!

loans.use: To purchase three calves and fodder

loans.name: Ramin

texts.en:
Ramin M., a 27-year-old man who breeds calves in a small village in the southern part of Azerbaijan, is directing all of his efforts to provide the best for his adorable daughter. He started his own business a year ago after having saved up enough money working on his father’s farm to purchase his own calves.

Ramin is a hardworking person, awaking at 5 a.m. to feed his calves and look after them throughout the day. He would now like to expand his business and so is requesting a loan of $1200 to purchase four more calves. Ramin is counting on your generosity!

loans.use: To purchase four calves.

loans.name: Musa

texts.en:
Musa B. is a 32-year-old entrepreneur who keeps calves and sells milk in a small southern village of Azerbaijan. He also works as a builder, but in his village construction is rare and thus not a stable source of income. Musa started his current business in 2002 when he borrowed money from a friend to purchase calves which he raised and then sold for a profit. He is now quite experienced in this business, having learned how to vaccinate and raise his calves to healthy adulthood.

Musa have only one problem - meeting the financial needs of his family which consists of his elderly father, mother and younger sisters. To improve this difficult financial situation he is requesting a loan of $1200 to expand his business and thereby increase his profit. With this money he will purchase one milking cow, two baby calves and fodder.

loans.use: To purchase a milking cow, two baby calves and fodder.

loans.name: Sabit

texts.en:
Sabit A., an enthusiastic 22-year-old, operates his own food store in a small village in southern Azerbaijan, selling sugar, tea, cigarettes, gum and salt. In this business since 2006, he has become very experienced and now knows the best establishments from which to purchase his commodities at the best prices.

Sabit is now requesting a loan of $1200 to purchase more food inventory, and he thanks everyone for their help and support.

loans.use: To purchase candies, beverages and canned food.

loans.name: Mehrali

texts.en:
Mehrali H., a 45-year-old farmer who breeds calves in southern Azerbaijan, is married and has four children, three sons and one daughter. While very proud to be the father of a big family, he laments the fact that his family is very poor, calf-breeding being their only source of income.

To expand the business and earn greater profit, Mehrali needs additional funds and so is requesting a loan of $1200 to purchase four calves. Let’s do our best to help this father of four!

loans.use: To purchase four calves.

loans.name: Shade

texts.en: Shade makes a living selling clothes, shoes and bags. Demand for her goods is high, and she has been in this business for a long time. Shade is 36 years old and married with four children. She lives in Okoko, Lagos state, Nigeria, and is a LAPO client. She has applied for a loan to buy more clothes, shoes and bags to sell, and extends her thanks to everyone who makes this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more clothes, shoes and bags to sell

loans.name: Veronica

texts.es:
Verónica se dedica a la comercialización de ropa mas que todo de cholita ( Blusas, enaguas, chompas y camisones)
Tiene un puesto en la zona El Rosario y su domicilio se encuentra ubicado en la zona de Alto chijini ambos ubicados en la Ciudad de La Paz
El crédito será destinado para la compra de mercadería para su puesto y poder ofrecer una diversidad de ropa.
Es la tercera vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, y la segunda vez que solicita el apoyo de Kiva, su historial la califica como cliente 1 es decir con cumplimiento bueno en el pago de su crédito.
texts.en:
Veronica sells clothing, most of all of cholita (blouses, petticoats, sweaters and nightgowns). She has a stand in the El Rosario area and her home is in High Chijini, both of which are located in the city of La Paz. The loan will be used to purchase merchandise for her stand and to offer a variety of clothes. This is the third time she has applied for credit with Impro, and the second time she has sought the support of Kiva. Based on her loan history, she is customer #1 because she completes her loan payments.

Translated from Spanish by Amani Roland, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase more blouses, petticoats, sweaters and nightgowns for her clothing business.

loans.name: Vicenta

texts.es:
La señora Vicenta vive en alquiler en la calle Alcoreza de la zona de Villa Nuevo Potosí de la ciudad de La Paz; tiene una tienda de abarrotes a una cuadra de su casa , con cuya actividad sustenta su alimentación y necesidades mensuales.

El crédito que solicita es para la compra de arroz, fideo y otros productos para poder surtir su tienda y de esta manera mejorar sus ingresos 

La señora trabaja con Impro desde hace mucho tiempo y tiene un historial de pagos muy bueno y por lo tanto califica para obtener un nuevo crédito.
texts.en:
Vicenta lives in a rental apartment on Alcoreza Street in the Villa Nuevo Potosi area of the city of La Paz; she has a grocery store a block from her house, which provides for her monthly expenses.

She is requesting a loan for the purchase of rice, noodles and other products to supply her store and improve her income.

She has worked with with Impro for a long time, has a very good payment history and thus is eligible to obtain a new loan.

Translated from Spanish by Amani Roland, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy rice, noodles, and other products for her grocery store.

loans.name: Ajoke

texts.en: Ajoke is 45 years old and married with four children. She makes a living sell kerosene to customers who visit her small shop. She has been in this business for a long time, and is a LAPO client. Ajoke says that the small amount of capital she been able to borrow from LAPO Microfinance has increased her business in recent years, and she would like to increase it even more. To make this possible, she is applying for a loan to buy more kerosene to sell. She is very grateful to LAPO Microfinance and Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To buy more kerosene to sell

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is a hair stylist who also sells hair extensions, hair cream and other products. She has been in this business for a long time, and now lives with her husband and four children in Igbelerin, Lagos state, Nigeria. She is a LAPO client, and has applied for a new loan to buy more items such as hair extensions and hair cream to sell. She wishes to express her profound gratitude to Kiva lenders and LAPO Microfinance for their financial support.

loans.use: To buy more hair extensions, hair cream and other items to sell

loans.name: Mayungbe

texts.en: Mayungbe lives in Lagos state, Nigeria, where she makes a living selling baking materials. Mayungbe is 49 years old, married and has four children. She is a LAPO client, and has applied for a new loan to buy more baking materials to sell to her customers. She wants to extend her thanks to Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To buy more baking materials to sell to her customers

loans.name: Linda

texts.en: Linda makes a living selling cooked foods like rice, beans and plantain and also sells drinks in her shop. She wakes up in the morning as early as 5:30 a.m. to start preparing food to sell. Linda cooks all day long, every day from  Mondays to Sundays. She is 40 years old and married with four children. Linda has been in this business for a long time, and is requesting a loan to buy more drinks to sell and foodstuffs to cook for her customers. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more drinks and food

loans.name: Los Montones Group

texts.en:
Martha S. has lived a very difficult life. Her whole life she has been living in extreme poverty and has not found a way to generate a steady income. She is a 55-year-old single mother of two children. She came to Esperanza International in hopes of receiving a loan so she could start her own business, and she sees this opportunity as a way to change her fortune and to give her a purpose.

She has always wanted to be able to provide a good life for her children, and be able to travel and have her own house. Martha is going to start a small business selling clothing in her area, and is so excited to get started. She is going to buy cheap clothing and fix it herself to sell. She really feels like a change is coming for her and her family, and she is ready to do whatever it takes. She is a really hardworking woman. We are all excited about her future!

Martha represents a "Bank of Hope," of which she is one of 10 members.

loans.use: Buy material to make clothing

loans.name: Adetoun

texts.en: Adetoun is happily married with four children. She is 42 years old and lives in Afro-media, Lagos state, Nigeria. Adetoun makes a living selling drinks, pepper soup and fried meat in her shop. She has been in this business for a long time, and works hard to meet the demands of her customers. Adetoun has applied for a loan to buy more drinks to sell in her shop. She says thank you to everyone who helps make this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more drinks to sell

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en: Deborah U. is a hair stylist. She also sells hair extensions and hair creams in her shop. She is 26 years old and married. she lives in Afro-Ajamgbadi, Lagos state, Nigeria. She hopes for the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more hair extensions and  hair cream to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions  and hair cream to sell.

loans.name: Con Dios Hacia Delante Group

texts.en:
Maribel is a hardworking mother of three children. She is the representative of this group of 20 people and a great example of the type of people Esperanza International deals with. She came to Esperanza International with no job, and no way to help her husband care for her three young. The family was going through hard times and her husband was having a hard time earning sufficient money to proviD. for the family.

Maribel took out a loan and started a business selling small pets. She found great success, and now is taking out her fifth loan and increasing the business. For the first time in her life she feels useful and feels like she has a purpose. She is able to proviD. for her family and to send her children to school. She is very happy with the success she has, but wants to keep increasing her business and bettering her life and the life of her family. She is very excited about the future, and the even more excited about the future of her children!

loans.use: Buying animals for breeding and selling

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice is a successful businesswoman who believes that hard work is the key to success. She makes a living selling provisions in her shop located along Kasidi Road in Okoko, Lagos. Beatrice is 47 years old and has three children. She has borrowed from LAPO Microfinance for the past three years and has also led a loan group. She has always made her payments on time. Beatrice needs a loan to buy more provisions to sell. She is very grateful to LAPO Microfinance and Kiva for their financial support.

loans.use: To buy more provisions to sell to her customers

loans.name: Emma Albertina

texts.es:
Emma pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres de Grandes Retos”, del distrito de Independencia, provincia de Huaraz, departamento de Ancash.

Emma tiene 46 años de edad y es casada. Las dificultades más grandes que tuvo fue en que un tiempo su esposo no trabajaba y ella tenía que ver por sus cuatro hijos. Hace 20 años se dedica a comercializar animales menores. Comenta que al empezar sólo contaba con S/.10 y que poco a poco ha ido creciendo, tan es así, que ahora tiene invertido en todo su negocio alrededor de S/.4,000. Los días de compra casi siempre es semanal, menciona que tienen mayores venta cuando requieren sus productos en fiestas especiales como día de la madre, día del padre, fiestas patrias y navidad. Trae sus productos del callejón de Huaylas, busca los productos de más bajos precio, de tal manera que puede venderlos a mayor precio en la ciudad de Huaraz, específicamente en la esquina de Juan de la Cruz Romero con la Av. Antonio Rayomdi. Como vendedora ambulante, su principal dificultad es que a veces los animales mueren y eso hace que disminuya la inversión. 

Con este préstamo de S/.1,700, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, invertirá en la compra de pavos para las fiestas navideñas.
 
A Emma le gustaría capacitarse para mejorar en su vida familiar y en su negocio.
texts.en:
Emma is 46-years-old and is married. She went through a hard time when her husband was unemployed and she alone had to make ends meet for their four children. About 20 years ago she decided to get into business raising small livestock such as rabbits, hens, and turkeys. She tells us that when she began she only had the equivalent of $3 USD to invest in her business but she been able to invest more money, little by little, up $1,280 USD today. She takes her animals to market nearly every week and tells us that her sales are higher during holidays such as Mother’s Day, Father’s Day, national holidays and Christmas. She checks prices on Huaylas street, so that she can sell her animals for the best price in the city of Huaraz. Her greatest difficulty is that at times one of her animals dies and then, naturally, she cannot sell it on and she loses her investment. With this loan of $550, which Emma will repay in four installments, she will purchase turkeys in advance of Christmas holidays. This loan will help Emma improve her business and the life of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Ann Molloy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of turkeys

loans.name: Janina Irma

texts.es:
Janina forma parte del Banco Comunal “Las Triunfadoras de Nicrupampa”, del distrito de Independencia, provincia de Huaraz, departamento de Ancash.

Tiene 33 años de edad y es madre soltera de una niña. Comenta que aún cuando ha tenido que trabajar desde muy joven para apoyar a sus padres, considera haber tenido éxito en su vida personal, debido a que ha logrado establecer una librería en el pasaje Las Dalias Mz.20 Lt.08 en Nicrupampa. Gracias a la ayuda de un tío que la apoyó para establecer este negocio y que poco a poco ha diversificado con la venta de útiles, también de juguetes y de productos de belleza. Estos productos los trae desde la ciudad de Lima y le llegan a pedido.
 
Con este préstamo de S/.1,000, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará útiles complementarios como lapiceros, plumones y cajas de colores.
 
A Janina le es importante seguir creciendo económicamente.
texts.en:
Janina is 33-years-old and a single mother with one daughter. She tells us that although she has had to work very hard since she was very young to support her parents, she considers herself successful because she has established a bookshop in Nicrupampa, thanks to the help of an uncle who supported her while she was starting her business. She has gradually diversified her business to include school supplies, games, and beauty products. She brings these products in from Lima. With this loan of $325, which she will repay in four installments, she will purchase items such as mechanical pencils, felt tipped pens, and boxes of crayons. It is very important to Janina and her daughter to continue to improve her financial position.

Translated from Spanish by Ann Molloy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase items such as mechanical pencils, felt tipped pens, and boxes of crayons

loans.name: Ejiro

texts.en: Ejiro sells frozen foods for a living, and travels to the Republic of Benin to buy items to sell to her customers. Ejiro is a 36-year-old widow and needs to support herself and her only child.  She has applied for a loan to buy more frozen foods such as turkey and fish to sell to her customers. Ejiro is a LAPO client and wants to thank Kiva's lenders and LAPO Microfinance for their financial support.

loans.use: To buy more buy frozen foods to sell

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
Julia pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres de Grandes Retos”, del distrito y provincia de Huaraz, departamento de Ancash.

Tiene 50 años de edad y es madre soltera de 4 hijos, además tiene un nieto a su cargo. Su principal dificultad fue tener un conviviente que la maltrataba y también tener que separarse para empezar sola su vida junto a sus cuatro hijos. Su más grande logro ha sido sobresalir, iniciar un negocio y construir su casa. En la actualidad comenta que se siente tranquila porque con su negocio de venta de peluches, regalos y celulares está creciendo mucho. Su tienda está ubicado en la Av. Fitzcarrald 247 desde hace un año. También comenta que por primera vez inició un negocio con S/.88 y que gracias al primer crédito que le otorgó el Movimiento Manuela Ramos por medio de su Banco Comunal, ha crecido mucho. En estos momento tiene invertido en su negocio un promedio de s/.50,000 en toda su mercadería.

Con este préstamo de S/. 3,000, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, invertirá en la compra de juguetes para la campaña navideña.
 
A Julia le encanta la idea de seguir creciendo, tanto en su negocio como en su vida personal.
texts.en:
Julia is a 50-year-old who is a single mother of four children and also cares for her grandson. Her greatest difficulty in life was having a partner who was abusive. This resulted in their separation and Julia having to start a new life with her four children. Her greatest accomplishment has been to rise above this by starting her own business and building her own home. She tells us that she is happy these days because her business, where she sells wigs, gifts, and cell phones, is doing so well. She also tells us that her business, which she began with the equivalent of only $25 USD, has grown a great deal thanks to the first loan she obtained through the Manuela Ramos Group. At this point she has been able to invest $15,900 USD in her store and merchandise. With this loan of $975, which she will pay back in four installments, she will purchase games and toys for the Christmas season. Julia is so happy with the idea of continuing to grow both personally and economically through her hard work.

Translated from Spanish by Ann Molloy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of games and toys for her store

loans.name: Temitayo

texts.en: Temitayo is 35 years old and married with four children. She makes a living selling children's clothing and underwear. She has been in this business for the past 10 years, and is determined to lift her family above poverty by increasing the size of her business. Temitayo is a LAPO client, and is happy to see the holiday season approaching because it means that demand for her goods will increase. Temitayo needs the loan to buy more clothing to sell, and wants to offer her thanks to everyone who makes this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing to sell

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Joy maks a living selling kerosene and engine oil from her house. She is very happy with this arrangement because she does not have to pay rent for a shop. Joy is a 50-year-old widow with three children who lives in Issashi, Lagos state, Nigeria. She is a LAPO client, and has applied for a loan for two purposes: to buy more kerosene to sell to her customers, and to go into the business of selling them drinks as well. She says thank you to all the Kiva lenders who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy drinks and kerosene to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Celestino Minaya

texts.es:
C. forma parte del Banco Comunal “Mujeres de Grandes Retos” del distrito de Independencia, provincia de Huaraz, departamento de Ancash.

Tiene 31 años de edad, es casada con un profesor y no tiene hijos. Menciona que su principal logro ha sido tener un puesto en el segundo piso puesto 02 del mercado central de Huaraz. Vende ropa y joyas, debido a que la venta en este puesto es lenta, tiene que salir a vender a las casas de sus clientes. Empezó su negocio con S/. 25 y ahora comenta que tiene invertido en todo su negocio aproximadamente entre S/. 5,000 a S/. 6,000 en ropa, zapatos y joyas. Su principal dificultad es que los productos que brinda a crédito no le pagan o no le pagan a tiempo. Afirma que trabaja para ella y que los ingresos que le brinda su esposo son específicamente para la casa.
 
Con este préstamo de S/. 3,000, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, invertirá en la compra de prendas de vestir para adultos, ropa para niños y zapatos. Todos los productos serán traídos desde las ciudades de Lima y de Trujillo.
 
C. comenta actualmente se encuentra bien en su negocio, pero de todas maneras le encantaría recibir talleres para mejorar su negocio. 
.
texts.en:
C. belongs to the Mujeres de Grandes Retos ["Women Facing Great Challenges"] community bank in the Peruvian "departamento" of Ancash. She is 31 years old, married to a teacher and has no children. She says that her main achievement has been to set up a space on the second level of the central market in Huaraz. She sells clothing and jewelry. Because sales in the market have been slow, she has to go out to her customers' houses to sell. She began her business with S/.25 [25 Peruvian soles] and she tells us that she's invested somewhere between S/.5,000 and S/.6,000 in clothes, shoes and jewelry. The main problem for her is that the products she sells on credit don't pay or only pay over time. She says that she works for herself and her husband's income is specifically for household expenses.

With this loan of S/.3,000, to be repaid in 4 installments, she will invest in buying articles of clothing for adults, children's clothing and shoes. All the products will be brought from the cities of Lima and Trujillo.

C. says that she's doing well with her business now but she would still like to attend workshops designed to help her improve her business.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products for resale.

loans.name: Niño Emanuel Group

texts.en:
The Niño Emanuel (“Emmanuel Child”) Village Bank is located in the Ccachuaram community of Ascensión District, in the Huancavelica Department of central Peru. This community is located two kilometers from the city. 

Ernestina C. lives with her common-law husband and their five children. Her husband is a baker, and she helps him distribute bread to different stores in the morning, then she sells bread at the door of the bakery. She needs this loan to buy fruitcake for the Christmas season. Her dream is for her children to graduate with professional degrees and to be able to pay for a course so that her husband can learn to bake new products to be more competitive in the market. 

Teodora Alfonso is divorced. She has been selling prepared meals at local markets ever since her husband left her. Teodora is in delicate health. She would like to buy more utensils for the meals that she sells to help expand her business. She wants her children to go to school and to graduate with professional degrees. 

Antonia R. is married and sells sweets near the entrance of a school in the Ascensión District. She got the idea for this business years ago, but her husband’s income wasn’t enough to start. With loans, she has been able to offer more products, and with the income she earns she helps pay for household expenses and the cost of schooling her children. Antonia is saving to pay for college for her son, who is finishing high school this year. 

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow

El Bancomunal Niño Emanuel, ubicado en L. comunidad D. Ccachuaram en el distrito D. Ascensión en L. provincia y departamento D. Huancavelica. Esta comunidad se encuentra a 2 kilometros D. L. ciudad.

Ernestina C., es conviviente, tiene 5 hijos, su esposo es panadero y le ayuda a repartir en las mañanas pan a todas las tiendas, después elL. misma se pone a vender en L. puerta D. L. panadería. Necesita su préstamo para invertir en L. preparación D. panteones por campaña naviD.ña. Su sueño es que sus hijos sean profesionales y poder pagar un curso para que su esposo pueda variar en L. preparación D. productos y poder competir en el mercado.

Teodora Alfonso, es divorciada, desD. que su esposo L. abandonó se dedica a L. venta D. comida en ferias los sábados y domingos. Teodora se encuentra delicada D. salud, le gustaría comprar mas utensilios para L. venta D. su comida y así incrementar su negocio, pues desea que su hijo estudie y sea profesional.

Antonia R., es casada, se dedica a L. venta D. golosinas en L. puerta D. una escueL. del distrito D. Ascensión. Hace años tenia esa idea pero no le alcanzaba con los ingresos D. su esposo, con sus prestamos incrementa mercadería y con las ganancias aporta en su casa y ayuda con los gastos D. L. escueL.. Antonia esta ahorrando para L. inscripción D. L. Universidad D. su hijo que este año termina el colegio.

loans.use: To buy fruitcake, utensils and sweets

loans.name: Maritza Rosario

texts.es:
Maritza forma parte del Banco Comunal “Mujeres de Grandes Retos” del distrito y provincia de Huaraz, departamento de Ancash.

Maritza tiene 34 años de edad y 3 hijos junto a su conviviente que es profesor. Su logro más grande ha sido ser independiente y generar sus propios ingresos sin pedir a su conviviente. Comenta que su principal dificultad ha sido tener un hijo enfermo del oído y cuyo tratamiento es muy costoso, de tal manera que lo que su padre gana no alcanza para todos esos gastos, es por ello que empezó hace un año el negocio de venta de comidas y bebidas y el del servicio de fotocopiado e impresión. Ha logrado la licitación de un cafetín dentro de un colegio, en la institución educativa parroquial “Santa Rosa de Viterbo”. Comenta que empezó con S/. 50 y que ahora tiene invertido aproximadamente S/. 2,500 en todos sus productos. Le va bien y afortunadamente tiene la licitación por dos años para lo cual podrá postular nuevamente al concurso. Su dificultad es que los días de vacaciones no podrá trabajar en su negocio.
 
Con este préstamo de S/. 2,500, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, invertirá en la compra de una impresora y recordatorios para las promociones.
 
A Maritza le es importante trabajar para salir adelante y apoyar a su familia.
texts.en:
Maritza belongs to the cooperative bank “Mujeres de Grandes Retos” (“Women of Great Challenges”), in the district and province of Huaraz, in the Ancash department. Maritza is 34 years old and has three children with her partner who is a teacher. Her greatest achievement is being independent and generating her own income. She tells us that her biggest difficulty has been having a child with an ear infirmity which requires costly treatment. For this reason, what the father earns is not enough for all the expenses, and she started to work a year ago selling food and beverages as well as providing photocopy and printing services. She has managed to bid on a cafeteria lease within a school, the parochial school Santa Rosa de Viterbo. She comments that she started with 0.50 soles, and has to date invested approximately 2,500.00 soles into her products. Things are going well and, fortunately, she holds the lease for two years at which time she will be able to renew the term. One problem is that, on vacation days, she won’t be able to work in her business. With this loan of 2,500.00 soles, to be repaid in four installments, she will invest in the purchase of a printer and promotional commemorations. It is very important to Maritza to work to get ahead and support her family.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a printer and promotional commemorations.

loans.name: Bolale

texts.en: Bolale makes a living selling fruit and jewelry which is made from various materials. She is 42 years old, married and has five children. Bolale opens her business at 7 a.m. and closes it at the end of a long day at 8 p.m. In between those times, she spends the entire day selling her goods by going from street to street in her community. Bolale is a LAPO client, and needs this loan to buy more fruit and more jewelry and materials to make it from. Bolale is very thankful to LAPO Microfinance and Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To buy more fruit and more jewelry and materials to make it from

loans.name: Sikiru

texts.en: Sikiru lives in Badagry, Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells wine and drinks in her house. Sikiru purchases her drinks and wine from Idumota market. She is 50 years old, married, and has five children. She is very energetic and business oriented. Sikiru needs a loan of 80,000 NGN ($700 USD) to purchase more wine and drinks. She appreciates the kind gesture shown to her by Kiva lenders and LAPO Microfinance.

loans.use: To buy wine and drinks

loans.name: Carmelina

texts.es:
Carmelina forma parte D. Banco Comunal “Señor D. Cautivo II” D. distrito y provincia D. Huaraz, departamento D. Ancash.

Carmelina tiene 37 años D. edad y 3 hijos junto a su conviviente. Afirma que se encuentra bien, que a pesar D. haber venido desD. L. ciudad D. Lima, ha salido adelante. Comenta que empezó gracias al apoyo D. su cuñado quien le hizo un traspaso D. sus productos, también menciona que ha crecido regularmente porque ahora venD. ropa, lentes, discos, relojes, los cuales trae desD. L. ciudad D. Lima. VenD. D. manera ambulatoria en L. esquina D. L. Av. Luzuriaga y el Jr. José D. L. Mar en L. ciudad D. Huaraz. Por ahora todo se encuentra bien y tranquilo.
 
Con este préstamo D. S/. 2,300, el cual será cancelado en 8 cuotas, invertirá en L. compra D. casacas D. cuero y pantalones.
 
A Carmelina le gustaría recibir talleres D. capacitación, principalmente para mejorar su negocio.
texts.en:
Carmelina is a member of the communal bank called “Señor D. Cautivo II” from the district and province of Huaraz in the state of Ancash. Carmelina is 37 years old and she has 3 children with her living partner. She tells us that she is doing very well, even though she has arrived from the city of Lima, she has been able to move ahead. She tells us that she started her own business, thanks to her brother-in-law, who help help her a little with the selling of products. She also tells us that her business has grown a little bit more since now she also sells clothes, sunglasses, cd's, watches which she brings from the city of Lima. She sells from door to door in the avenues between Luziaga and Jr. Jose D. L. Mar in the city of Huaraz. For now, everything is good and calm. With this loan, which she will repay in 8 months, she will purchase leather coats and pants. Carmelina would like to receive training courses as to how to better her business.

Translated from Spanish by Carolina Zelaya-Kronlund, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase leather coats and pants

loans.name: Esperanza El Coco Group

texts.en: Cirila C. is the representative of this group of five people. Cirila is from an extremely poor area in Samana, Dominican Republic. She is looking for a loan to help increase her small business of selling clothing. She buys clothing from other cities at a cheap price, then sells them in her area for a profit. Cirila is the mother of very young children, and is responsible for their health and education. Before her small business, she had no job and was barely able to feed her children. She started her small business with her first loan from Esperanza International, and has been slowly increasing her business. She feels like this next loan will really help her increase the business size, and start generating more income. She said that she finally feels like she has something of her own, and is so happy that she can provide for her children. She dreams of having both her children attend a university so they can have a better life. She is very excited for what the future holds for her!

loans.use: Buy clothing

loans.name: Herlinda Susana

texts.en: Herlinda is a member of the Nobleza (“Nobility”) Village Bank. Herlinda travels to regional fairs three times per week to buy grains, cheeses, animals, and anything else that she finds. She then brings her wares back with her to Ayacucho to sell wholesale. Herlinda also sells clothing in local markets. Herlinda is requesting a loan to buy grains and potatoes.  Her dreams are to have her own home, a stable business, and enough money to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy grains and potatoes

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
Juana forma parte del Banco Comunal “Señor Del Cautivo II” del distrito D. Independencia, provincia D. Huaraz, departamento D. Ancash.

Tiene 64 años D. edad y 5 hijos que ya no los tiene a su cargo, pero apoya, junto a su esposo, a sus nietos.
